### Additional context
Seems like the error is based on the data model.
The Tags Column is limited to 4000 chars:  [SqlServer](https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/blob/master/src/BaGet.Database.SqlServer/Migrations/20180804082816_Initial.cs#L34), [SQLite](https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/blob/master/src/BaGet.Database.Sqlite/Migrations/20180804082808_Initial.cs#L33)

In nuspec files of powershell modules all public function are listed in tags, so sometimes they get really long.

title: Add service url to the aws s3 configuration model
body:
Add the `ServiceURL` to configure a local AWS S3 cloud service.
The model will handle the validation, either `RegionEndpoint` or `ServiceURL` must be set. 

Addresses https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/271

title: Configure local AWS (S3) service
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I like to use a on-premise AWS S3 cloud service, which is running in my network locally.

### Describe the solution you'd like
The current configuration of amazon S3 client only use the `RegionEndpoint` property.
This field needs to get optional and a new property `ServiceURL` need to be definied.

Optional also the other [AmazonS3Config properties](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/sdkfornet1/latest/apidocs/html/T_Amazon_S3_AmazonS3Config.htm) could be implemented.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

### Additional context

title: chocolately search support
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Chocolatey client unable to search BaGet to install chocolatey packages

Steps to reproduce the issue

**Added BaGet as source**

```
C:\admin\projects\chocolatey\awscli>choco source add -n=poc -s="http://BaGet:5555"
Chocolatey v0.10.13
2 validations performed. 1 success(es), 1 warning(s), and 0 error(s).
Added poc - http://BaGet:5555 (Priority 0)
```

**Failure 0 package found**
```
C:\admin\projects\chocolatey\awscli>choco search
Chocolatey v0.10.13
2 validations performed. 1 success(es), 1 warning(s), and 0 error(s).

Validation Warnings:
 - A pending system reboot request has been detected, however, this is
   being ignored due to the current command being used 'search'.
   It is recommended that you reboot at your earliest convenience.

[NuGet] Not able to contact source 'http://BaGet:5555'. Error was Invalid URI: Invalid port specified.
[NuGet] Not able to contact source 'http://BaGet:5555'. Error was Invalid URI: Invalid port specified.
0 packages found.
```

**I have no problems pushing to Repo, only searching**
```
C:\admin\projects\chocolatey\awscli>choco push cwrsync.5.4.1.nupkg --source="http://BaGet:5555" --api-key="test123" --force
Chocolatey v0.10.13
2 validations performed. 1 success(es), 1 warning(s), and 0 error(s).

Attempting to push cwrsync.5.4.1.nupkg to http://BaGet:5555
cwrsync 5.4.1 was pushed successfully to http://BaGet:5555
```

### Describe the solution you'd like
Allow Chocolatey to search BaGet and be able to pull and install chocolatey packages

### Describe alternatives you've considered
None ATM

title: Allow a way to filter packages in DatabaseSearchService
body: In some cases, users might want to filter package search results according to a custom logic. Introducing a virtual method like FilterPackages in DatabaseSearchService.cs can help to do that.

title: Allow overriding PackageService methods
body: Allow overriding PackageService methods so that a new package service like MyPackageService can be inherited from PackageService instead of implementing IPackageService fully.

title: Missing NPM in the official docker image
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I am happy to see that there is an official docker image!
I am trying to run this on simple & clean server so NPM is not installed there. 
Is there a way to get NPM with the official image so I won't have to install NPM as
pre-requisite? there is no mention of that pre-requisite in DockerHub also.

pic attached at the end.

### Describe the solution you'd like
It will be great if the NPM installation will take place inside the docker image. 

### Additional context
Picture of the error:

![Screen Shot 2019-05-08 at 12 15 43](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33253167/57365596-08e48700-718e-11e9-85d0-cc7f3d7f3677.png)

title: Can BaGet authenticate with S3 via IAM roles?
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I do not want to use AccessKeys within AWS. I want to use assumed roles / instance profiles instead. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
The docs here: https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/cloud/aws/ describe AccessKey and SecretKey.
A quick fix would be if the AccessKey and SecretKey are not specified, fall back to using the InstanceProfile keys: AccessKey SecretKey and Token in the S3 client credentials for the requests. These can be obtained via the FallbackCredentialsFactory.GetCredentials() which returns a AWSCredentials object containing the AccessKey, SecureSecretKey and Token.

title: Update configuration.md
body:
Added endpoint configuration options. This is available since ASP .Net Core 2.1

Summary of the changes (in less than 80 chars)

Addresses https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/123

title: Import package from an existing Nuget.Server instance
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I'm am trying to do import all packages from our NuGet.Server instance, cause I want to replace it with a BaGet server. 

### Describe the solution you'd like
It would be great to get an option which downloads all packages from an nuget package server (api v2) to make them available on the BaGet server. 

#### Fallback idea
Provide a way to import nuget package from a folder structure created by the NuGet.Server. 

Best regards

Stefan

title: Publish on nuget.org
body:
First of all, thank you for such a great project :).

### Describe the solution you'd like

Are you willing to publish BaGet as a nuget package on nuget.org ? We want to use it as a NuGet package in our project. There is a nuget package on https://www.nuget.org/packages/BaGet but it seems like you have unlisted it.

Thanks.

title: Refactor BaGet
body:
Refactors BaGet:

1. Moves business logic out of controllers and into `BaGet.Core`. For example, the `PackageContentController` passes requests to `IBaGetPackageContentService` and maps results to HTTP responses. In effect, controllers are just translate HTTP translators.
2. BaGet's services for the NuGet protocol implement the same interfaces as BaGet's client libraries for the NuGet protocol. For example, `AzureSearchService` and `SearchClient` both implement `ISearchService`
3. Requests and responses are codified by models in `BaGet.Protocol`. For example, both `SearchController.SearchAsync` and `SearchClient.SearchAsync` return a `SearchResponse`

title: Generate XML docs
body: See https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/242

title: Refactor `BaGet.Core`
body: ⚠️ This change changes the namespace of most core types! These are breaking changes, BaGet's version has been bumped to `0.2.x-prerelease` to reflect this!

title: [Azure] Add Azure Table Storage database
body:
This is an experiment to support massive read/write throughput using Azure Table Storage. I'll be benchmarking this on Azure later. The moonshot goal is to scale this to 12,000 reads per second (~1 billion reads per day), as this is roughly NPM's scale.

* [ ] Perf test
  * [ ] Mass index
  * [ ] Perf test registration leaf
  * [ ] Perf test registration page
  * [ ] Perf test version list
* [ ] Consider adding `IPackageService.FindVersions` API to improve version list perf
* [ ] Consider adding a special row on each package partition that lists that package's versions. It's unclear how to implement this, maintaining this row should not harm write throughput but ideally this row should be strongly consistent

title: Clean up BaGet project file
body: Remove this piece https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/blob/master/src/BaGet/BaGet.csproj#L10

title: [Documentation] Revamp docs
body:
1. [ ] Improve existing docs
    1. [x] Rename "BaGet" to "Overview". Focus more on a high-level introduction to BaGet https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/
    1. [x] Fix list numbering [here](https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/#running-baget-on-docker)
    1. [x] `The following Mirror settings configures BaGet` -> `The following Mirror setting configures BaGet` https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/configuration/#enabling-read-through-caching
    1. [x] `BaGet will reject a package upload if the id and version is already taken` -> `BaGet will reject a package upload if the id and version are already taken` https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/configuration/#enabling-package-overwrites
    1. [x] Remove `which` from hyperlink in `which App Engine region` https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/cloud/gcp/#running-baget-on-google-cloud
    1. [ ] `Read under, "Application Pools" and, "Application Pool Identity"` Remove extra commas https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/windows/iis-proxy/#baget-folder-permissions
    1. [ ] Document how to find the service index for MyGet, AzDO, etc [here](https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/configuration/#enabling-read-through-caching)
    1. [x] Rename "VSTS" doc to "Azure DevOps Artifacts"
    1. [ ] Update "LiGet" doc https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/vs/liget/
    1. [ ] Shorten API key example. `dotnet nuget push -k NUGET-SERVER-API-KEY -s http://baget/v3/index.json  package.nupkg` https://loic-sharma.github.io/BaGet/configuration/#requiring-an-api-key
1. [ ] Rearrange docs around "Quick starts"
    1. [ ] Command line
    1. [ ] Docker
    1. [ ] Azure
    1. [ ] AWS
    1. [ ] Google Cloud
    1. [ ] Windows IIS
1. [ ] Add "Configuration" for each database, storage, and search providers.
1. [ ] Document the `BaGet.Protocol` package

Also see https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/28

@amandasong

title: [UI] Fix several bugs
body: Addresses https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/209, https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/225, https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/252, https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/250, and https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/253.

title: PowerShell modules breaks page width
body:
### Describe the bug
Hosting PowerShell modules with BaGit breaks page width caused by tag list

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Using BaGit version `v0.1.75-prerelease`
  - installed on fresh ubuntu 18.04 lts VM with dotnet-core.2.2 sdk
2. Configure nginx as proxy via:

````nginx
server {                              
  client_max_body_size 100M;          
  listen 80;                          
  server_name baget;                  
  location / {                        
    proxy_pass http://localhost:5000/;
  }                                   
}                                     
````

3. Publish any PowerShell Module like `WinSCP`
4.  Page width increases with every exported Powershell cmdlet/function.

### Expected behavior
There should be a shorted version of the tag list or a dedicated page listing all the tags

### Screenshots
![Imgur](https://i.imgur.com/JzsbOSn.png)

### Additional content

If you try to shorten the module tags by providing the paramerter `-tags` this content will be added to the default values. This means the tags will be pared like this: `<tag param values>, <exported function list>`

title: [UI] Unlisted packages still appear on UI
Issue #224: Added additional symbol route for Visual Studio 2017
body:
Summary of the changes (in less than 80 chars)

 * Added a route proposed by @ivony tested with a local build and VS 2017 pro.

Addresses https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/224

title: [UI] Incorrect package installation instructions for dotnet tool
body: Instructions should show `dotnet tool install --global <package> --version <version>`

title: [Protocol] Mirror nuget.org's undocumented protocols
body: NuGet.org uses RDF to generate its V3 API. This adds properties that aren't part of the official API, however, certain clients depend on these undocumented properties.

title: [Search] Use Office Fabric to style filters
Improve upload instructions
body:
Fixes instructions for uploading using Paket and adds instructions for PowerShellGet.
 
See https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/235

title: Update docs with Google AppEngine instructions
body: Closed #244 by accident and pushing to the branch didn't reopen it. This PR updates the docs with a typo correction and link to Google Cloud SQL instructions; sorry for the inconvenience.

title: Unable to upload symbols
body:
### Describe the bug
I'm not able to upload symbol file using nuget

C:\Program Files (x86)\Jenkins\workspace\libLogger>c:\nuget\nuget.exe push "C:\Program Files (x86)\Jenkins\workspace\libLogger\bin\Debug\Logger.*.snupkg" 1234567890 -Source http://192.168.21.42:5000/v3/index.json 
Pushing Logger.2.0.0.snupkg to 'http://192.168.21.42:5000/api/v2/symbol'...

title: HTTP Error 500.19 with IIS setup
body:
### Describe the bug
Server responds with an HTTP Error 500.19 with an IIS setup after trying to access it from another machine.
Full error information:

_ | _ | _ | _
------------ | ------------------ | ----------------- | --------------
**Module** | IIS Web Core | **Requested path** | http://localhost:5000/
**Notification** | Unknown | **Physical path** | 
**Handler** | Not yet determined | **Logon method** | Not yet determined
**Error code** | 0x8007000d | **Logon user** | Not yet determined
**Config error** | 
**Config file** | \\\\?\C:\inetpub\wwwroot\BaGet\web.config | |

**Config source:**
`
-1:
0:
`

The error happens both on localhost and remote PC, **after first trying to access the server from another PC.**

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Using version of BaGet.zip 0.1.70
2. Unpack to C:\inetpub\wwwroot\BaGet\
3. Follow steps from documentation to install as an IIS, including adding folder permissions.
4. Access from the server itself to http://localhost:5000/ and observe that the home page works as intended.
5. Access from another PC on the network to http://servername:5000/ that already has access to other working services on the server (ex.: Jenkins) and observe a 500 internal error.
6. Access from the server itself again to http://localhost:5000/ and observe an HTTP Error 500.19 with the error information provided earlier.

### Expected behavior
Being able to at least access the home page from the server itself.

### Additional context
I am basically following the steps in `Getting started` and `IIS setup` without touching any configuration file.

title: Authentication for mirrors / read through caching
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
I want to use BaGet as a read-through cache so that I can restore nuget packages while online, then go offline and be able to restore again successfully.  Unfortunately, while most of my nuget packages come from nuget.org, some packages come from private feeds that require authentication.

### Describe the solution you'd like
I'd like to be able to specify a username and password as part of setting up the mirror options in appsettings.json and have that be used when downloading packages from the remote source if the package isn't found locally.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Another option would be to read the nuget.config file to get this information the same way the nuget client does or to try to use the nuget client itself to do the download.  Those solutions seem like they would be more involved than duplicating this configuration information next to the mirror package source url in appsettings.json

### Additional context
In the absence of some other idea, I intend to implement this feature for my use in a fork of BaGet and will be happy to create a pull request if you would be interested in adding that capability to the main project.  Chances are, though, that I will only have time to implement basic authentication using username and cleartextpassword--not support for apikeys and encrypted passwords unless those turn out to be quite easy to include.

title: Registration should display the full version string
body: Currently the registration resource displays the normalized versions. This is incorrect as the full version string (including the build metadata) should be displayed. This happens because the database stores only the normalized version.

When there is a package with a long name, the text does not wrap to a new line, but it runs into the right column.

title: support new symbol download url pattern
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
baget symbol server is not works in VS2017.
in VS2017, it download symbol file like:
http://baget-host/api/download/symbols/Ne/Newtonsoft.Json.pdb/1F194FBE703D4FCFA949C251C3CCCDE4ffffffff/Newtonsoft.Json.pdb

it's not like

http://baget-host/api/download/symbols/Newtonsoft.Json.pdb/1F194FBE703D4FCFA949C251C3CCCDE4ffffffff/Newtonsoft.Json.pdb

so, it not match baget symbol download route rule.


### Describe the solution you'd like
we can add a new route rule to fix the problem.

```
routes.MapRoute(
  name: Routes.SymbolDownloadRouteName,
  template: "api/download/symbols/{prefix}/{file}/{key}/{file2}",
  defaults: new { controller = "Symbol", action = "Get" });
```

title: V2 protocol read through caching
body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
More and more component providers are moving to providing their commercial components through private nuget feeds. Unfortunately, it seems many of them seem to prefer (or rely on a product that only implements) the V2 protocol.
To the best of my knowledge, it seems BaGet needs a V3 service index to be able to use read-through caching/mirroring.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Support reading V2 indices.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
Handle mirroring outside BaGet.
Transform a V2 index to a V3 index for Baget

title: UNC paths for packages
body:
This may be more confirmation than anything else.

On Windows IIS server, I wanted to store the packages on a network share. I found that I could give permissions to the share for the machine, FRED$ itself and that worked up to a point - the folders were created under the directory but no .nupkg files were created - a 500 error returned.

The Path for packages I was using :  "////share/folder"

I believe the issue might be with the format I'm using for the path, or perhaps the fact that BaGet is running behind IIS using Application Pool identities - for which there would be no way for me to assign those identities to the share folder since it's on another machine entirely.

Lack OF OData integration in `baget` 2. PowerShellGet not being compatible with v3 NuGet Feeds (though it can publish which is _weird_ and it shows up in a generalized query. 3. `baget` not publishing the type property/not handling the publishing of PS Modules correctly. 4. `type`, though expected, isn't generated by the v3 spec 5. Operator Error - I've tried defining the PowerShell repository several different ways and it always throws the same, or similar errors of `missing type property` ### Expected behavior The module is published in the correct format and installs correctly from the `baget` NuGet Feed ### Screenshots If applicable, add screenshots to help explain your problem. ### Additional context Is anyone using baget to serve PowerShell modules? Is there another Docker image which I should be using for this? If so, which would you recommend? ### UI Screenshot ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6684332/52015588-f29ca000-24a7-11e9-9b45-9e65dbdbcf09.png) I've been bashing my head against this for two days, so thank you so much for any suggestions you might have.

title: - increase multipart body length limit
body: Addresses https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/191

title: BaGet with MySql/MariaDB
body:
Hi All,

I wished to use BaGet hosting the database on a MariaDB server.

So I downloaded the sources and added the support for MySql with Pomelo.EntityFrameworkCore.MySql NuGet.

All works fine except the SearchAsync() function of DatabaseSearchService class.

The request 
            var packages = await _context.Packages
                .Where(p =>
                    search.Select(p2 => p2.Id)
                        .OrderBy(id => id)
                        .Distinct()
                        .Skip(skip)
                        .Take(take)
                        .Contains(p.Id))
                .GroupBy(p => p.Id)
                .ToListAsync();
never returns.

If I rewrite it 
            var packages = await search
                .Distinct()
                .Skip(skip)
                .Take(take)
                .GroupBy(p => p.Id).ToListAsync();
the function returns results.

Any idea?

I will upload my code when it works if you wish.

Regards,
Stephane

title: Feature Request: Enable package overwrites
body:
### Describe the solution you'd like
An option to replace packages with matching version number would be nice. Right now, even with ```HardDelete``` set, I still get ```409 - conflict``` when replacing the package. I read about the whole left-pad thing, and I understand it, but our organization's needs are different. It would help if the UI allowed for proper package management, but I understand it is in early stages, and it is looking GREAT!

We are currently using [phpNuget](https://github.com/kendarorg/PhpNuget), which supports deletion and replacement, but we are seeing very slow activity in the development and are looking for other options.

title: Are symbol files corrupt?
body:
### Describe the bug Symbol files downloaded from BaGet as symbol server cannot be opened by a debugger. ### To Reproduce Steps to reproduce the behavior: 1. Using version 0.1.32-prerelease of BaGet 2. Run BaGet `dotnet BaGet.dll` 3. Have a package `MyPackage.1.0.0.nupkg` with `MyPackage.dll` and its symbol package `MyPackage.1.0.0.snupkg` containing its *portable* PDB `MyPackage.pdb`. 4. Upload this NuGet package. ``` powershell nuget push -Source http://localhost:5000/v3/index.json MyPackage.1.0.0.nupkg ``` Output: ``` log Pushing MyPackage.1.0.0.nupkg to 'http://localhost:5000/api/v2/package'... PUT http://localhost:5000/api/v2/package/ Created http://localhost:5000/api/v2/package/ 555ms Your package was pushed. Pushing MyPackage.1.0.0.snupkg to 'http://localhost:5000/api/v2/symbol'... PUT http://localhost:5000/api/v2/symbol/ Created http://localhost:5000/api/v2/symbol/ 125ms Your package was pushed. ``` 5. In Visual Studio, add the NuGet package `MyPackage.1.0.0` from the BaGet server to a csproj that generates an executable. 6. Configure `Tools → Options → Debugging → Symbols` to add symbol server `http://localhost:5000/api/download/symbols` with a symbols cache folder. 7. Launch the csproj with Visual Studio debugger attached. See that Visual Studio is not able to load the PDB for MyPackage. 9. Go to the symbol cache folder and open `MyPackage.pdb` (supposed to be downloaded from BaGet) with a text editor to see that its content seems to be an html page: ``` html BaGet
``` ### Expected behavior The content of the PDB file provided by BaGet should be the same as the content of the PDB from the symbol package uploaded.

title: Official DockerHub image
body:
It would be great if there was an official BaGet Docker image hosted on DockerHub, there are currently several 'unofficial' copies using various out-of-date versions.

I think it would be quite easy for the CI platform to push the built Docker image to DockerHub once any tests have passed, as the image itself is already built as part of the pipeline.

My main motivation for requesting this is to use an 'official' image with the Helm chart that I'm putting together for BaGet so that I can run BaGet on Kubernetes easily. I'll link the Helm PR here once I'm done.

title: Separate server controllers into a dedicated project and publish as package
body:
### Feature

Separate the BaGet controllers (and other associated code, like `HttpRequestExtensions`) into a dedicated project that will be built into a package and published.

### Why?

It would be awesome if the BaGet controllers could be consumed as an independent package. This could allow one to compose his/her own server implementation without making changes to the main BaGet project, while still benefiting from any additions, improvements or bug fixed that will be made to this area of the code in the future. Examples for things this change will allow  - 

1. Creating custom default behaviors.
2. Easily integrating a different UI, or just dropping it all together.
3. Supporting other configuration methods/providers/conventions.
4. Cancelling the inclusion of auxiliary packages (e.g. AWS, Azure, EF) if they are not used.
5. Change hosting solutions easily (which is actually where I'm coming from).

### My use case

I'm thinking of creating a serverless BaGet server over AWS. The idea is to have the server hosted as a Lambda function and exposed through AWS ApiGateway. Storage will be S3 based (which I saw is  pretty much supported already), and I'll create a PackageService and a SearchService that are based on AWS SimpleDB.

At the end you have a private BaGet server in the cloud that costs nothing except for the S3 storage for the packages (so, virtually nothing).

### Cons

- A package that you can just import into an empty asp.net project and have a full server isn't exactly something common, and maybe there is a reason for that ([although it wouldn't be the first](http://nugetserver.net/)).
- Could make the project a bit more complicated, at least at a glance (because the `BaGet` project, which is the server, won't have any controllers in it).

### Pros
 - Would make it very simple to create custom BaGet based package feeds, which may get more people to use it on more platforms.
 - Would make BaGet the only open source .net-core project that allows this kind of flexibility and extensibility, as far as I could find.

Support for [Chocolatey](https://chocolatey.org/).

Lifted a lot of the core logic from https://github.com/ai-traders/BaGet.
Created Legacy namespace and tried to keep everything contained, would prefer if Choco added nuget api v3 support.

### Closes Issue(s)

#43 

At least partially, OData queries can be very expressive, I dont know to what extent old nuget clients use it.

### Motivation

Need it, and want to reuse the same server software between nuget and choco.

### Additional Notes

Would like some help in structuring this in a better way, support for api v2 got added but code became more complex. Not sure if its worth the cost. But the lack of support turned out to be a deal breaker for us.

title: Added MySQL server support
body:
### What does this PR do?

Adds MySQL server support.

### Motivation

Need it. Sort of gave up on getting PostgresSql to work.

### Additional Notes

Sadly the current entity framework provider doesnt support the `LIMIT` keyword in queries. So `DatabaseSearchService` couldnt fetch packages. Added another service that doesnt do the linq take or skip, which is currently not a great loss since the paging doesnt appear to be used anyway (?). Cant find an issue for this in their github repos, will try to find the time to reproduce this minimally and create one.

title: [WIP] Added support for re-indexing all missing packages on startup.
body:
### What does this PR do?

Adds support for, on startup, to go through all packages in the store and re-adds them to the database.

### Motivation

The intention is to have the option to treat the sqllite database living inside the container as a throwaway cache, since the container is rarely restarted and its one less connection to secure.

### Additional Notes

Could use some more work, but I wanted some feedback on this feature and the general approach. One thing of note is that the downloads count for packages would be reset if the docker container is restarted (something we dont care about).

title: Added env var to specify other appsettings
body:
### What does this PR do?

By launching the app with environment variable `APPSETTINGS_ROOT` set that folder will be used to look for appsettings.json files.

### Motivation

The appsettings.json file contains sensitive information. We are hosting on Kubernetes and are mounting sensitive settings and certificates in a secret volume. This mount, and thus it files, cant go in the root, they need a subfolder. As such, I need a way to override where it looks for the settings file. There might be a more elegant way to do this.

title: SQLite Error 5: 'database is locked
body:
**EDIT 11/11/2020**: This issue should now be fixed on newly created BaGet databases. Older installations can circumvent this issue by enabling write-ahead logging on your SQLite database. You can check if your SQLite database has write-ahead logging enabled by running the query `PRAGMA journal_mode` and getting the result `wal`. If necessary, you can enable write-ahead logging by running `PRAGMA journal_mode=WAL;`.

title: Improve BaGet's service registrations
body: Addresses https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/pull/152 and https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/156.

title: [WIP]: Add Type decompilation services
body:
Adds assembly decompilation to get an object representing the package or assembly in question. Uses Mono.Cecil to read  the IL code, and ILSpy's decompiler to convert IL code in to C# code -- all in all avoiding loading of the assemblies into the host process.

#### Decompilation
* Types (names of types)
* Methods, Constructors (return type, name)
* Properties, Fields, Events (return type, name)
* C# declaration of above elements, e.g.: `public void MyMethod(string somevalue);`

Is by no means complete, but more information can be extracted as needed.

#### Source code
I've created a little interface to post-populate the decompiled assembly with source code. The idea is to have multiple ways of fetching the sources, in some preferred order, for example:

* Embedded sources in pdb (possible in portable pdb's? `EmbedAllSources` ?)
* Embedded sources in Nupkg archive (`src/..`)
* SourceLink sources from the internet (read sourcelink json from pdb, somehow link types to C# files, fetch those files ..)
* Decompiled sources from IL code <-- I've made this one

#### Usage, right now

I've not created any code to link it to BaGet yet. But right now, you could run the decompiler like such:

```csharp
using (var reader = new PackageArchiveReader(@".\TMDbLib.1.3.2-alpha.symbols.nupkg"))
{
    var res = new NugetDecompilerService(new AssemblyDecompilerService()).AnalyzePackage(reader);

    // use res
}
```

Part of #140

title: UI: Show package dependencies and dependents
body:
Add a UI feature to show package dependencies (what _this_ package depends on), and dependents (which _other_ packages depends on _this_ package) -- within the BaGet system ofc.

Links to other packages may have to be "closest possible".

* PackageA depends on PackageB.1.0.0
* PackageB only exists in version 1.2.0
* PackageA's page should show a dependency of `PackageB >=1.0.0`, but link to `PackageB 1.2.0` (maybe have a warning sign)

title: IOptionsSnapshot<T> cannot be used from Singletons
body:
`IOptionsSnapshot<T>` [cannot be used from singletons](https://github.com/aspnet/AspNetCore/issues/2380).

Issue is present in the ApiKey authentication service. I workarounded it by registering the auth service as scoped.

title: Support for multiple feeds
body:
Like myget.
Under different URL's:
```
/f/buildtools-dev/v3/index.json
/f/core/v3/index.json
```

title: Allow PDBs to be stored in a compressed form
body:
Allow customers that generate large amounts of PDBs to store these in compressed snupkg form. These symbols should be extracted when requested, on the fly. See: https://twitter.com/dotMorten/status/1070402374714281984

Follow up to: https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/130

title: Support Windows PDBs
body:
This is necessary for C++ packages. See: https://twitter.com/dotMorten/status/1070402827112013824

Follow up to: https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/130

title: Use previously unused FileStorage service
body: The FileStorage service wasn't added to the service collection. This PR adds it.

title: Fixing line endings
body: Attempt at resolving som EOL issues

title: Replace own IS_DOCKER by base image DOTNET_RUNNING_IN_CONTAINER
Make it possible to configure the API key without hashing.
body:
Passing passwords unhashed is a common technique in containers.
Such passwords are stored and shared in the container platform.

title: Refactor configuration validation
body:
Configuration are now registered using `services.ConfigureAndValidate<MyOptions>(...)`. This verifies that the configs' values match the option's annotations.

/cc @LordMike

title: Add new storage abstractions
body:
See this conversation: https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/pull/144#issuecomment-443544711

Adds a new interface, `IStorageService` for low level storage APIs. This interface is implemented by `FileStorageService` and `BlobStorageService` for Azure. All package content operations are now managed by `PackageStorageService` regardless of the low-level storage implementation.

/cc @LordMike

title: Add S3 storage service
body:
(do not merge)

### What does this PR do?

Implements an S3 storage service

### Closes Issue(s)

Fixes #136

### Motivation

If we deploy BaGet, we'll need S3 storage support :)

### Additional Notes

This code has not been tested, yet. I'd like some feedback before proceeding. It's basically a copy off of the Azure project, with the search removed. I've replicated the configuration validation methods etc.

title: Improve the display package UI
body:
Adds a Package Download link and removes the License Info link when a package has no license.

Addresses  the issues https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/138 and https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/141 found by @LordMike.

title: Feature: Retention policies
body:
In cases where the nuget package store is used as a target of CI pipelines, the number of packages will quickly grow. Adding some form of retention policy could be very useful.

Ideas for retention policies: 

* Delete packages at a certain age (time, or number of version behind "newest")
* Delete only pre-release packages at a certain age (keep all "release" packages)
* Keep packages that, f.ex., are:
  * In use by others
  * Downloaded X times
  * Marked as "must-keep" in the UI

The database could keep a record of deleted packages, so that if a request comes in for it, a different kind of error can be produced, or maybe the UI could show a warning.

title: UI: Add download links directly in UI
body:
### Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?

Feature

### What did you expect to see?

MyGet has a UI feature / link where you can quickly download a `nupkg` or `symbols.nupkg` when viewing a given package version.

title: Feature: Show, index and search Types within packages
body:
### Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?

Feature

### What did you expect to see?

It'd be awesome for companies and groups using BaGet, to be able to search for Types within their packages. Since the number of packages is relatively small (compared to Nuget), it should be doable.

Internally, we usually have the question, "I know we have a XYZ helper, but I can't find it", so searching in a neat and fast UI would be very helpful, and be something most projects don't have.

I imagine that the following things be searchable:

* Public types (Instance types, statics, abstracts, interfaces, structs, ..)
  * Name, Full name, Xmldocs if present
* Public methods (`GetFileInfo()`)
  * Name, Type, Xmldocs if present
  * This is a maybe - search results may be too cluttered with 100's of `ToString()`'s
  * Some methods should be ignored, such as all those of `object`, `IDisposable`, .. 

If we go further, special care would be taken for:

* Roslyn analyzers
  * Name of analyzer
  * Names of individual analyzers, quickfix tools, etc.
  * Xmldocs if present

title: UI: Add setup page describing how to add the repository to nuget config(s)
body:
### Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?

Feature

### What did you expect to see?

* A link or page describing how to add the Package Repository to a `Nuget.config`
  * Either the users config file
  * Or a project-specific `Nuget.config` file.
* The page should include the actual url, and in case of Private Feeds (#36), a key (if possible) in the feed url

I imagine that next to the BaGet title, an "info" or "setup" link could be added.

body:

title: UI: Deletion of packages
body:
### Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?

Feature

### What did you expect to see?

* A delete button next to a package (all versions)
* A delete button next to a package version
* A delete button for many packages, perhaps all at once

In other words, are there any high level plans for the web ui?

title: AWS support (S3)
body:
Hi,

What is needed for S3 support? I can see the Azure project has a few things in it:

* Blob service
* Search service using Azure Search

This directly translates to:

* S3 storage (can we do it so that end users download from S3 directly?)
* AWS CloudSearch (never used it)
  * Is search necessary? Wouldn't a query in the EF DB be enough?
  * I imagine most queries want to prefix match on the Package Id anyways

Would implementing an S3 client be enough?

title: Make BaGet a symbol server
body:
Allows BaGet to: 

* Index symbols from [`.snupkg`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/create-packages/symbol-packages-snupkg) packages
* Serve symbols using the [Simple Symbol Query Protocol](https://github.com/dotnet/symstore/blob/master/docs/specs/Simple_Symbol_Query_Protocol.md#simple-symbol-query-protocol-ssqp)

See: https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/130

title: Build docker image as part of CI
First launch fix
body:
### What does this PR do?

Fixes build and run nuget server on docker.

### Motivation

When cloned the latest version of master was not able to build and run docker image from scratch.

### Additional Notes

Fixes include:
    - changed Baget.UI folder references to correct ones (BaGet.UI) because microsoft dotnet images are based on debian linux and is case sensitive for the forlder names
    - ignored SouceLink msbuild targets for docker builds because you do not need debugging experience inside container (and it build failed because of these targets)
    - updated publish stage to install nodejs inside dotnet sdk image because it do not include nodjs and dotnet publish command causes BaGet.UI npm commads to run

title: Fix docker build
body:
### What does this PR do?

Fix docker build.

### Closes Issue(s)

#129

### Motivation

Need to be able to build docker image locally to make changes.

### Additional Notes

title: Make BaGet a symbol server
body:
BaGet should:

1. Have an endpoint to ingest [symbol packages (.snupkg)](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-Us/nuget/create-packages/symbol-packages-snupkg)
2. It should be able to extract portable PDBs embedded into a nupkg
3. It should be able to respond to symbol server requests. See [this API documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/azure/devops/symbol/?view=azure-devops-rest-4.1)

See https://github.com/dotnet/symstore/blob/master/docs/specs/Simple_Symbol_Query_Protocol.md
See https://github.com/dotnet/symstore/blob/master/docs/specs/SSQP_Key_Conventions.md
See https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/src/System.Reflection.Metadata/specs/PE-COFF.md
See https://github.com/dotnet/corefx/blob/master/src/System.Reflection.Metadata/specs/PortablePdb-Metadata.md

See https://github.com/dotnet/symstore/tree/master/src/NugetSymbolServer

/cc @karann-msft

```
RUN dotnet build src/BaGet -c ${APP_BUILD} -o /app
RUN dotnet publish src/BaGet -c ${APP_BUILD} -o /app

will be replaced with those:
```
RUN dotnet build src/BaGet -c Release -o /app
RUN dotnet publish src/BaGet -c Release -o /app
```

It looks like argument is not evaluated properly.

title: Package not found in primary source error
Incorrect version reported as latest
body:
BaGet seems to report the incorrect version number as the latest version:

eg: here's the main home page showing build 168 as the latest:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/179862/48038884-b0283780-e1c6-11e8-9255-a15b1836c297.png)

but when I click on it, 172 is really the latest:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/179862/48038908-d0f08d00-e1c6-11e8-9885-93b0245d51b7.png)

The "Manage NuGet Packages" command in Visual Studio also shows the incorrect latest version.

Also, the last updated time stamp says 11 hours ago, but this was just uploaded 10 mins ago.

Restarting the server didn't help.   Pulling latest version of BaGet didn't help.

Could this be something about the way the package is authored confusing BaGet?

Brad

title: Set up CI with Azure Pipelines
Improve storage
body:
This change:

* Improves the documentation
* Refactors the storage layers
  * Moves some sync code to async
  * Accepts cancellation tokens in more places
* Adds an option to hard delete packages. See https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/111

title: Add configuration option for application root URL
body:
<!--
PLEASE READ THIS MESSAGE.

HOW TO WRITE A GOOD PULL REQUEST?

- Read the contributing guide: https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md.
- Make it small.
- Do only one thing.
- Avoid re-formatting.
- Make sure the code builds.
- Add tests.
- Write useful descriptions and titles.
- Address review comments in terms of additional commits.
- Once approved, please squash your commits to avoid polluting the commit history.
-->

### What does this PR do?

<!-- A brief description of the change being made with this pull request. -->
This pull request adds the setting `PathBase` to the BaGet configuration and applies this setting on startup. The `PathBase` option allows an ASP.NET Core application to run under a different root URL than it was designed for.

### Motivation

<!-- What inspired you to submit this pull request? -->
I want to operate a BaGet server with a URL like https://example.com/baget and reach the API index at https://example.com/baget/v3/index.json. With this change I don't have to write complex rewrite rules for this scenario which might not work at all.

### Additional Notes

<!-- Anything else we should know when reviewing? -->
[Deal with path base and proxies that change the request path](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/host-and-deploy/proxy-load-balancer?view=aspnetcore-2.1#deal-with-path-base-and-proxies-that-change-the-request-path) on Microsoft Docs

title: Better support for running under supervisorctl via SIGTERM support
body:
Currently BaGet waits for Ctrl+C to shutdown.  This makes it incompatible with supervisorctl as a way to monitor/control BaGet running on a server - supervisorctl can start the process but fails to stop it properly, leaving dotnet processes running in the background.

See this this post where the developers of supervisorctl make it quite clear that Ctrl+C to stop a running process is not, and won't ever be supported.  https://github.com/Supervisor/supervisor/issues/555

It's be great if BaGet could shutdown cleanly in response to a SIGTERM.

title: Mirroring fails unless Nuget.Common is added explicitly
body:
I was trying to set up Nuget.Org mirroring and the MirroringService was throwing an exception every time a request was made that "Nuget.Common 4.7.0.x" was missing. 

I found this to be an issue when trying to set up the server from scratch. I built the source in Visual Studio and ran once, then disabled the Nuget.Org feed in VS2017 and enabled the read through caching. The app would then throw an exception on line 71 of MirroringService.cs (this is from memory). Problem is that I now have that package cached locally and so can't recreate the issue.

My fix was pretty simple; if I add the Nuget.Common.4.7.0.nupkg to both the Baget and BaGet.Core projects, the pass through cashing now works first time. It's such a small change, but it seems to make the server happy.

I have a branch with the fix in it (and also the appsetting.json was changed to meet our needs, so I won't do a pull request from that branch...) It's probably worth adding that in though, as it wasn't obvious as to what was failing until I stepped through the code.

https://github.com/memsom/BaGet/tree/Fixes/make_readthrough_work

title: Improve build system; add e2e tests, docker CD, FAKE, paket
body:
### What does this PR do?

 * This PR contains a rebase and some fixes of #101 . @solidsloth I hope you are fine with me rebasing your commit and integrating with FAKE. In #101 quite a few things did not want to work at the same time. You could either get debugging work, tests or production build. I have taken care of this now. 
 * Added test which checks that built image returns contents of SPA site
 * It includes all of #103, which is:
   1. Adds `Idefile`, which is a reference to [docker IDE image](https://github.com/ai-traders/docker-dotnet-ide), which contains all build dependencies (dotnet, node.js, yarn, bats for e2e tests). If you have local docker daemon then you can run any of the build tasks like this now `ide <command>`. E.g. `ide ./build.sh` will run msbuild publish and run tests with xunit.
   2. Updates travis setup to run:
       - msbuild publish in release config
       - run tests of the published artifacts
       - build docker image from those artifacts
       - test that docker image is functional
   2. Moves dependency management to paket.
   3. Adds FAKE and targets to run most of above workflow.
 * It includes all of #105, which is:
    * It changes the way to build docker image. By always using the result of `msbuild /t:Publish` in the docker image. And we are not using docker BUILD container, but using the same artifacts that were tested in previous stage.
    * added a flag to skip running db migrations. By default it is ran. As mentioned in discussion in #101
    * added e2e tests, mostly ported from LiGet. 
       - We create some packages, push, download with nuget cli and paket. 
       - These can run on travis from now on

Dockerfile is changed a bit:
 * uses tini for init system to reap any processes.
 * does not run as root by default. There is a `baget` user.
 * because of above changes default listening port to 9090.
 * when container starts it changes uid and gid of `baget` user based on owner of volume mount.
 * environment variables are all specified in Dockefile for clarity. Now a basic server to try out can be run with `docker run baget`.

### Closes Issue(s)

#57 #56 #101 #7 

### Motivation

In general - I need BaGet to be functional and tested before I can use it in production. I don't want to waste time on testing features and fixing bugs which get randomly broken because there are no tests, no reproducible builds and no release cycle.

Why `Idefile` and [IDE project](https://github.com/ai-traders/ide):
 - biggest advantage is to reduce the noise around works on my machine. Now anyone can download the same environment which all developers and travis agents are running for builds.
 - rather than spending time on setting up your host, (either laptop or the CI agent) just pull the image which someone has already created and tested to be sufficient to execute entire workflow of the project

Why paket:
 - paket gets consistent package versions across all projects and it can support modules for FAKE.
 - `paket.dependencies` gives you an quick overview of all packages used by application. 
- `paket.lock` gives you detailed info about each version of all direct and transitive dependencies.
 - I tried to install xunit.runner.console without using paket. But there is no such command on `dotnet` SDK. There is no nuget CLI for linux which works without mono, and I managed to keep away from mono so far.

Why FAKE:
 - we get consistent AssemblyVersion for all projects, from top of changelog file.
 - it provides single source of truth on what the release cycle and tasks involved.
 - fake is cross platform and can do much more than just msbuild. (See how hard it was to copy a few files in #101)
 - programming tasks in xml is not easy and error prone. In F# FAKE you get as much as type safety in build scripts.
 - for all other task, which cannot be covered by msbuild or dotnet cli, we need a cross platform language. Otherwise windows guys start to code in powershell and linux guys in bash. We need something friendly to both platforms.
 - F# is cool

Why I am running tests with `dotnet ...xunit.console.dll <assemblies-from-publish-dir>`?
The main point in CD is that artifacts which constitute the application should be produced just once and then ran through all QA stages. We really need to be testing exactly the same files at each point until final release to ensure quality. In dotnet world that means using `dotnet publish` to force outputting application and all all its dependencies.
One of the common issues I had with dotnet assemlies is that running with dotnet test adapter uses additional assemblies from nuget caches. So I've seen tests passing when ran with `dotnet test` or `dotnet xunit`, but when same test is executed with  `dotnet ...xunit.console.dll <assemblies-from-publish-dir>` it fails. Naturally same load errors happen in deployed application (after all tests have passed earlier...). So running tests with `publish` reproduces those errors and makes sure that we get load errors early.
PS: I actually ran into this already in BaGet and fixed it. The `Microsoft.AspNetCore.App` in BaGet.Tests was causing problems like this:
```
xUnit.net Console Runner v2.4.0 (64-bit .NET Core 4.6.26814.03)
System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions, Version=2.1.1.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=adb9793829ddae60'. The system cannot find the file specified.

System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions, Version=2.1.1.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=adb9793829ddae60'. The system cannot find the file specified.
```

### Additional Notes

I will be away for weekend, so I can have a look at review notes on Monday.
I am closing #103 and #105 , and I hope @solidsloth can close #101 since this contains the work and original intentions.

title: Port e2e tests from nuget.org
body:
### Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?

Feature

### What did you expect to see?

@loic-sharma suggested porting official nuget.org tests to baget. Thanks to that 
 * baget would be more compatible with original nuget.org behavior.
 * we have better test coverage with some real world examples and corner cases tested

### What I did

Since it sounds great, I took a few step to implement this, [here is a branch](https://github.com/ai-traders/NuGet.Services.EndToEnd/tree/core) in e2e tests, and here is in [baget](https://github.com/ai-traders/BaGet/tree/nuget.org-tests).
Some major obstacles are:
 * official tests run on .net framework. I already made a move to compile and run on dotnet core 2.1
 * there are a few references to non-open assemblies, which I removed briefly.
 * once I got the tests to execute against baget, it appeared that V2 is used all over the place to query for packages.

My conclusion is that it maybe not that easy/productive to port that project. Maybe rather rewrite some of the cases from scratch.
Or perhaps implement V2 well enough for the tests to pass, although that requires v2 search, which is not even in LiGet.
I am leaving it for now, since it is not that important and time consuming. I added a few basic e2e tests in bats in #105

title: v2/package endpoint does not match specification
Docker the right way
body:
This PR is on top of CD setup in #103. 

### What does this PR do?

 * It changes the way to build docker image. By always using the result of `msbuild /t:Publish` in the docker image. And we are not using docker BUILD container, but using the same artifacts that were tested in previous stage.
 * added a flag to skip running db migrations. By default it is ran. As mentioned in discussion in #101
 * added e2e tests, mostly ported from LiGet

Dockerfile is changed a bit:
 * uses tini for init system to reap any processes.
 * does not run as root by default. There is a `baget` user.
 * because of above changes default listening port to 9090.
 * when container starts it changes uid and gid of `baget` user based on owner of volume mount.
 * environment variables are all specified in Dockefile for clarity. Now a basic server to try out can be run with `docker run baget`.

### Motivation

The e2e tests ensure that some of the most basic commands, such as nuget push or paket install pass.
This step would be great to execute before publishing final docker image.
Most of this is LiGet's CD ported to BaGet.
The files in `.build` are part of our internal bash script helpers used for common stuff. This is added for reference, nothing fancy there.

title: Fix index versions and urls; add tests
body:
`/Versioned` looks like a leftover and this is definitely not the right version in any of the endpoints.
These changes were enough to fix paket install and update.

### What does this PR do?

 * Changes versions of resources in `index.json` to 3.0.0.
 * Adds trailing `/` in `PackageBaseAddress` and `RegistrationsBaseUrl` which were causing issues in paket too.

### Motivation

Currently running paket install or update would fail with
```
GetPackageDetails failed: System.Exception: Couldn't get package details for package baget-test1 1.0.0 on http://baget:9090/v3/index.json. ---> System.AggregateException: One or more errors occurred. ---> System.Exception: could not find an PackageIndex endpoint for http://baget:9090/v3/index.json
```
Which is caused by resource names in `index.json` being `RegistrationsBaseUrl/Versioned` rather than something like `RegistrationsBaseUrl/3.4.0`.

This is not passing all e2e tests yet.

title: [WIP] First things for maturity and CD setup; IDE, Paket, FAKE
body:
### What does this PR do?

3 things:
1. Adds reference to [docker IDE image](https://github.com/ai-traders/docker-dotnet-ide), which I have created earlier today. If you have local docker daemon then you can run any of the build tasks like this now `ide <command>`. E.g. `ide ./build.sh` will run msbuild publish and run tests with xunit.
2. Moves dependency management to paket.
3. Adds FAKE and draft of running tests CD-style.

### Closes Issue(s)

 * Related to #56  #57 
 * Soon will fix #96 after I start to build docker from artifacts produced by build stage

### Motivation and why

@loic-sharma I briefly spoke to you about some of this. You were asking what are benefits of paket and fake considering that msbuild is in place already.

Why paket:
 - paket gets consistent package versions across all projects and it can support modules for FAKE.
 - `paket.dependencies` gives you an quick overview of all packages used by application. 
- `paket.lock` gives you detailed info about each version of all direct and transitive dependencies.
 - I tried to install xunit.runner.console without using paket. But there is no such command on `dotnet` SDK. There is no nuget CLI for linux with works without mono, and I managed to keep away from mono so far.

Why FAKE:
 - we get consistent AssemblyVersion for all projects, from top of changelog file.
 - it provides single source of truth on what the release cycle and tasks involved.
 - fake is cross platform and can do much more than just msbuild.
 - programming tasks in xml is not easy and error prone. In F# FAKE you get as much as type safety in build scripts.
 - for all other task, which cannot be covered by msbuild or dotnet cli, we need a cross platform language. Otherwise windows guys start to code in powershell and linux guys in bash. We need something friendly to both platforms.
 - F# is cool

Why I am running tests with `dotnet ...xunit.console.dll <assemblies-from-publish-dir>`?
The main point in CD is that artifacts which constitute the application should be produced just once and then ran through all QA stages. We really need to be testing exactly the same files at each point until final release to ensure quality. In dotnet world that means using `dotnet publish` to force outputting application and all all its dependencies.
One of the common issues I had with dotnet assemlies is that running with dotnet test adapter uses additional assemblies from nuget caches. So I've seen tests passing when ran with `dotnet test` or `dotnet xunit`, but when same test is executed with  `dotnet ...xunit.console.dll <assemblies-from-publish-dir>` it fails. Naturally same load errors happen in deployed application (after all tests have passed earlier...). So running tests with `publish` reproduces those errors and makes sure that we get load errors early.
PS: I actually ran into this already in BaGet and fixed it. The `Microsoft.AspNetCore.App` in BaGet.Tests was causing problems like this:
```
xUnit.net Console Runner v2.4.0 (64-bit .NET Core 4.6.26814.03)
System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions, Version=2.1.1.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=adb9793829ddae60'. The system cannot find the file specified.

System.IO.FileNotFoundException: Could not load file or assembly 'Microsoft.Extensions.Logging.Abstractions, Version=2.1.1.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=adb9793829ddae60'. The system cannot find the file specified.
```

### Additional Notes

On the bad side, it runs on our private infrastructure and feedback will not be available to other contributors until we setup something. E.g. maybe server could post failures to the PR? @loic-sharma what do think?
I am not stressing that we (AIT) build it but I see no good CI provider which can give me a local docker host, which is necessary for e2e tests which I plan to add later.

Tests on debian stretch are fine after modifying `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` to include the directory with native extensions `tests/BaGet.Tests/bin/Release/netcoreapp2.1/publish/runtimes/linux-x64/native/`. Otherwise they fail with
```
System.DllNotFoundException : Unable to load shared library 'e_sqlite3' or one of its dependencies. In order to help diagnose loading problems, consider setting the LD_DEBUG environment variable: libe_sqlite3: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
      Stack Trace:
           at Microsoft.Data.Sqlite.SqliteConnection..ctor(String connectionString)
...
```

Tests on alpine fail with a core dump, I couldn't fix it yet
```
xUnit.net Console Runner v2.4.0 (64-bit .NET Core 4.6.26814.03)

title: WIP fix/implement caching upstream #93
body:
For read-through caching, queries to registration and package service
must be directed to upstream server. Otherwise client would get always
404 because there is nothing in the cache to begin with.
We can add caching queries too, but that requires integrating catalog
reader to refresh responses for already cached packages.


### What does this PR do?

Fixes read-through cache.

### Closes Issue(s)

#93

### Additional Notes

 * still need to add an option to parametrrize cache source. I don't think previous option was ever sufficient `"PackageSource": "https://api.nuget.org/v3-flatcontainer/"`. I think we need to specify full URL to the index of nuget server. Such as `"https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json"`.
 * this is working now, but there are 3 endpoints which work by checking local packages first and then fallback to ask nuget.org. I think it would be more sensible if caching endpoint was separate from private index. Please tell me if I can move it.
 * I'll add unit tests before merge.

title: Improved development environment
body:
### What does this PR do?

In development the application can now be run to proxy to the react development server. This resolves the problem where the code needs to be changed in development to point to the server correcly (which is running on a different port). I also modified the csproj file to have msbuild copy the required front-end files to the publish folder when needed. Therefore the built files no longer need to be copied over and permanently stored in the wwwroot because in development the requests are proxied, and in production the files are copied to the publish folder.

### Closes Issue(s)

I think [EnsureCreated](https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/compare/master...solidsloth:improve-develop#diff-9ad6d4f8918b56df444e175cefd23768R47) this might help with issue #96 because the database is now created in development. 

### Motivation

My main motiviation was to simplify the development and resole the issue about [bend URLs being broken in develop mode](https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/commit/1466885120f4c19621636ecdf8019145abf53ea6#diff-d6ae89e5d09a8b55b7470a25d69deb31R20). This allows the same workflow: `yarn develop` + `dotnet run` without needing to change any urls in `components/SearchResults.tsx`  or `components/DisplayPackage.tsx`

### Additional Notes

- I fixed the vscode `launch.json` file to work with the new netcoreapp2.1.
- I added a few artifacts to the gitignore to prevent accidental commits of the generated files, including: the .cache folder, the dist folder, and the SQLite database file.
- I removed the generated source files from the repo since these should be rebuilt upon every release.

title: Score packages off their quality
body:
Give packages a score based off of their quality. This should use the client's [`IPackageRule`s](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/3803820961f4d61c06d07b179dab1d0439ec0d91/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Packaging/Rules/IPackageRule.cs). Search can penalize packages with low quality.

Pub example: https://pub.dev/api/packages/pana/metrics?pretty

title: GitHub Integration for repository URL
body:
The number of open pull requests, open issues, and the last commit date should be fetched if the package has a repository URL.

These API calls should be kicked off by the client and should be unauthenticated. If the rate limit of 60 requests per hour is hit, the client should gracefully hide the GitHub details.

See the Visual Studio Marketplace: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=GitHub.vscode-pull-request-github

Use GitHub release information for changelog?

title: Update Program.cs & adding import script (fix "Request body too large" error).
body:
### What does this PR do?

First issue is about  fixing the "body too large" error when posting to BaGet repo. 
(push that exceeds 27 MB)

More over, another addition is python script, "pushPackage.py", that is meant to allow automatic
import of existed NuGet repository into BaGet repository. 
The script has parameters who have to be altered ( "<XYZ> syntax"). 
"failedPushes" is variable that presents directory and will serve to handle failed (status code != 200).
All failed packages will be located there for the programer's QA and fixes. 

### Closes Issue(s)
Addresses https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/88

### Motivation

I had this issue.
I had to import 300 packages from existing repository, that motivated me to create the script.

title: Cant list/see/install packages via Docker container
body:
### Do you want to request a *feature* or report a *bug*?

Bug

### What did you do?
Reproduction steps

- I clone the repository, 
- Then run `docker build . -t baget` 
- Then create `baget.env` file according to the wiki.
- Then `docker run --rm --name nuget-server -p 5555:80 --env-file baget.env -v "$(pwd)/baget-data:/var/baget" baget:latest`. The container starts up without any error messages.
- Then i try to push a nuget package I have with: `dotnet nuget push -s http://localhost:5555/v3/index.json -k NUGET-SERVER-API-KEY AccountReconciliation.RestAPI.Client.0.1.2.nupkg` which results in: 
```
info : Pushing AccountReconciliation.RestAPI.Client.0.1.2.nupkg to 'http://localhost:5555/v2/package'...
info :   PUT http://localhost:5555/v2/package/
info :   Created http://localhost:5555/v2/package/ 343ms
info : Your package was pushed.
```

### What did you expect to see?
I expect the website to show the pushed package. I expect `nuget list -s http://localhost:5555` to show `AccountReconciliation.RestApi.Client.0.1.2` and `nuget install AccountReconciliation.RestApi.Client` to download and install the package into my project.

### What did you see instead?

When I enter http://localhost:5555 there are no packages shown. 
If i try to run `nuget list -s http://localhost:5555` I get 
`WARNING: The remote server returned an error: (404) Not Found.
No packages found.`. 
If I try to install with: `nuget install AccountReconciliation.RestAPI.Client -Source http://localhost:5555` I get 
`WARNING: An error occurred while loading packages from 'http://localhost:5555/': The remote server returned an error: (404) Not Found.
WARNING: An error occurred while loading packages from 'http://localhost:5555/': The remote server returned an error: (404) Not Found.
Unable to find package 'AccountReconciliation.RestAPI.Client'.`

### Output of `git rev-parse HEAD`: (_What version of BaGet are you using?_)

```

title: Discussion about the new Options validation
body:
Hi
I'm talking about the following commit (specially OptionExtensions.cs)
https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/commit/bda4d6f27eab86b09cc2b543961741b6c4c95fd2

I like the idea to bring all the validations in one Point (SPOT=Single Point of Truth)

Where i'm strugeling is the usage pattern - basically do you allow

``
DatabaseOption option = null;
option.EnsureValid();
``

I understand that your code  works - because implemented as Extension!

But it stops my flow during a code review because calling methods on null pointer is working ONLY for extensions and a normal code reader is not able to see ad hoc that the method is a extension method.

A few ideas how to solve that (overengineering included)

- implement validations as instance methods direct inside the class
    - bool IsValid()
    - bool IsValid(out Exception)
    - void EnsureValid() { if IsValid(out e)==false throw e}

the null check can/should remain on the caller side OR (new idea)
- rename the extension Method in something that says: this is a extension and a call with null is allowed)
- inside the extension method check for null, and then call EnsureValid on the instance....

just my 2 cent.....

title: Split up the BaGet.Web project
body:
Right now, `BaGet.Web` is a netcoreapp2.1 project as it references `Microsoft.AspNetCore.App`. It should be split into two pieces:

1. Anything related to the serialization of NuGet's v3 protocol should be moved to a `BaGet.Protocol` project. This project should be netstandard2.0
2. The rest should be moved to the `BaGet` project.

title: Queue-based package ingestion
body:
Create a job that ingests packages from a queue. The ingestion should:

1. Be resilient to concurrency issues
2. Be resilient to dependency failures
3. Be extensible enough that it can support multi-regional scenarios

# High-level design

Upload flow:

1. Extract package identity
2. Check that the package doesn't exist in the database (`uploads` or `packages`)
3. Enqueue a message to index the package
4. Upload the package to storage (overwrites of the same package identity are disallowed)
5. Add the package identity to the `uploads` table in the database
6. If the metadata insertion fails, delete the package from storage

Background ingestion flow:
1. Search for package in `uploads` table in database. If it cannot be found:
    1. If we've reached some retry threshold, ignore the message
    2. Otherwise, sleep and retry later
2. Download package from storage
3. Validate the package
4. Extract the package's metadata
5. Add the package's metadata to the `packages` table if it doesn't exist already
6. Index package metadata in search

title: Prove BaGet's registration implementation
body:
BaGet's registration implementation is vastly different from nuget.org's. Both have pros and cons, but nuget.org cannot move to BaGet's implementation until BaGet is proven. This requires:

* [ ] Investigate BaGet's reliability
  * [ ] Investigate how to get even close to 16 9's of uptime
  * [ ] Investigate true geo-redundancy
  * [ ] Investigate Content Delivery Network caching for reliability
* [ ] Investigate BaGet's read performance
  * [ ] Scale to 100 requests per second for parity with nuget.org
  * [ ] Stretch goal: scale to 1,000 requests per second 

# A Comparison of BaGet vs nuget.org

## nuget.org

nuget.org generates static JSON files for each registration artifact. These files are uploaded to Azure Blob Storage using geo-redundant storage and are served behind a Content Delivery Network.

* Pros
  * **Reliable**. Azure Blob Storage is very reliable (16 9's of uptime using geographically redundant storage).
  * **Near infinite read performance**. The registration is just a bunch of static files that can be served directly. This scales *incredibly* well.
* Cons
  * **Hard to change**. Adding a new field to the registration necessitates a rebuild of the registration.
  * **Hard to verify**. Each JSON file must be verified independently. nuget.org has a job that crawls through artifacts to verify that they contain the same data as the database.
  * **Low write performance**. It is difficult to parallelize the job that updates the registration. This hampers write performance.
  * **Blocking**. Bugs in the job that updates the registration can cause the ingestion pipeline to halt.

**Note**: Although nuget.org has multiple copies of its V3 resources, each registration copy is not truly highly available. If the registration's primary region becomes unavailable, that registration resource will also become unavailable. This isn't listed as a con as this is a fixable issue.

## BaGet

BaGet stores its package metadata in a database. Each request is served by a BaGet service that queries the database for the metadata and then serializes it into JSON.

* Pros
  * **Easy to change**. A new field field can be added to the registration by deploying a new version of BaGet.
  * **Write performance**. BaGet can index many packages in parallel. BaGet can handle and recover from concurrency issues that bubble up from the database.
  * **Verifiable**. The database is the source of truth and its package metadata has constraints.
* Cons
  * **Reliability**. 16 9's of uptime is incredibly difficult to achieve for a service. This can be mitigated with geo-redundancy. Uptime is nuget.org's number one concern, thus, this is the primary blocker for adopting BaGet's registration implementation.
  * **Read performance**. As each read requires a database query, read throughput is limited by the database. Caching can be used to mitigate this.

title: Show source repository information
body:

See [the source repository spec](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Show-source-repository-information-for-packages-on-nuget.org), the [issue to add source repository information to V3 resources](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6262), and [this pull request](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/pull/6151#issuecomment-406685381) that added the source repository information to the Gallery.

title: [WIP] Add support for private feeds
body:
# Private Feeds

⚠️ This is still a work in progress

This adds support for private BaGet feeds using Azure Active Directory authentication. The experience is as follows:

1. The user runs `dotnet restore` for the first time on their private BaGet feed
2. The NuGet client shows the message:

> To sign in, use a web browser to open the page https://microsoft.com/devicelogin and enter the code ABCD123456 to authenticate.

3. After the user logs in using their browser, BaGet grants the user access to the private feed
4. The NuGet client continues the restore operation

Addresses https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/36

## TODO

* [X] Backend
  * [X] Support Azure Active Directory authorization
  * [X] Accept the JWT token using HTTP Basic Auth
* [ ] BaGet frontend authentication
* [ ] NuGet client authentication plugin. See [this branch](https://github.com/nkolev92/BaGet/tree/master-AddBasicCredentialProvider)
* [ ] Polish
  * [X] Disable the authentication if there are no AAD settings
  * [ ] Documentation

For a prototype of the client side code that will be used by the NuGet plugin, see: https://gist.github.com/loic-sharma/dca161747f13a62a6bcf8b1d04259445

/cc @nkolev92

title: Make BaGet a single executable
body:
Use .NET's IL Linker to reduce BaGet into a single executable.

For more information: https://github.com/dotnet/core/blob/master/samples/linker-instructions.md

Builds on top of https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/issues/62

title: Adopt the new self-contained nupkg spec
body:
# Overview

NuGet packages will soon be able to store icons, licenses, and documentation directly in the nupkg. See this spec: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Packaging-Icon,-License-and-Documentation-within-the-nupkg

# Icon

BaGet should fetch the icon at ingestion time and store it in the flat container. See https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Packaging-Icon-within-the-nupkg

# License

BaGet should support SPDX licenses and should also extract licenses stored within the nupkg. See https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Packaging-License-within-the-nupkg

# Documentation

BaGet should support the new `Documentation` nuspec property. Today, BaGet looks for files named `readme.md` or `readme.txt` (see [this code](https://github.com/loic-sharma/BaGet/blob/master/src/BaGet.Core/Extensions/PackageArchiveReaderExtensions.cs#L24)). The `Documentation` property should be prioritized over the presence of such files.

For more information, see this spec: https://github.com/NuGet/Home/wiki/Packaging-Documentation-within-the-nupkg.

As I was setting it up to host our internal nuget packages, I kept running conflict issues when my files weren't even there. My motivation was to harden the implementation a little bit, without changing any of the client expectations (it will still return a 409, for instance)

title: Improve BaGet command line experience
body:
All tools should be folded into the main BaGet executable. To start, the commands should be:

* `baget` - Launch the BaGet server
* `baget mirror <url>` - Import all packages from an upstream source
* `baget mirror <path>` - Import all packages from a local feed
* `baget mirror package <id> <version>` - Import package(s) from an upstream source
* `baget mirror downloads` - Fetch download counts from nuget.org
* `baget azure search import` - Import the BaGet database into Azure search

More commands will be added later:

* I'd like a friendly installation experience that prepares BaGet's settings
* A command will be added to support queue-based package validation/ingestion

Look into https://github.com/natemcmaster/CommandLineUtils

Look into https://twitter.com/natemcmaster/status/1123281393377693696
