title: Support multiple listeners
body: This would allow, for instance, to service both IPv4 and IPv6 clients with a single instance.

title: Use the proper data structure in death queue
body:
It currently uses a ring buffer, which don't allow reordering. Change that to a proper queue, so that reordering after updating the time to die is possible.

Recent changes made some space available in the connection structure, which is exactly what's necessary to build a linked list using integer indices to an array (could be re-purposed from the current death queue).

title: Implement small string optimization in strbuf
body: Store small strings in the space used by the length integers and buffer pointer.

title: Reduce amount of locking in caches
body:
Investigate how feasible it would be to reduce the amount of locks in the caching infrastructure.

One possible way of doing this is to, in addition to the current cache infrastructure, to have a hash table per CPU, each one containing proxy entries for the master hash table. Each proxy entry holds one reference to the master entry (updated with atomic operations), and will have its own reference count (which does not require atomic operations to update). Lookups on these hash tables also require no locking. Removing items from these tables could happen as soon as the last proxy reference is dropped (at which time the reference for the master hash table is also dropped).

It should be possible to implement this without changing the API.

This sacrifices some memory but potentially beats replicating the whole cache per CPU.

title: Can't change config settings via struct initializer
body: And other small fixes...

title: Fix ipv6
body:
I like the new listener line but we can't pass in the brackets from the IPv6 addresses.

I've also changed the listening message to always show numeric IP addresses because the translated names with brackets aren't valid URLs, e.g. http://[localhost]:8080.

title: IPv6 support
body:
This adds IPv6 support via a new "ipv6" config option.

I'm not sure if this option is the ideal way to enable it but it's probably the simplest for now. It may be better to have getaddrinfo() infer the protocol version based on a provided address from a more flexible listener line (e.g. "listener [::]:8080 {"), similar to [nginx's listen directive](http://wiki.nginx.org/HttpCoreModule#listen).

I've also made IPv4 the default, but it may be better to use IPv6 while ensuring IPV6_V6ONLY is turned off so that [IPv6 sockets can accept both IPv4 and IPv6 clients](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1618240/how-to-support-both-ipv4-and-ipv6-connections).

title: Improve templating engine
body:
Things that might be useful implementing:
- triple mustache to automatically escape strings
- ~~inverted sections~~
- ~~comments~~

title: License issues
body:
I hate to bring this topic up, but I feel like lwan is rather heavily restricted as potentially embedded webserver library.

Instead of GPL, why not LGPL (with an exception to permit static linking), similar to ZeroMQ (see http://zeromq.org/area:licensing)?
It would seem more fitting for library-style software.

title: Investigate if POSIX_FADV_SEQUENTIAL behaves like MADV_SEQUENTIAL
body: MADV_SEQUENTIAL on madvise() will free pages that have been accessed -- which isn't particularly good for our use of posix_fadvise() with a similar flag. Maybe POSIX_FADV_WILLNEED is better?

title: Race condition when pruning items from cache
body: If item is destroyed after setting item to floating but before doing so in pruner job, a double free might happen.

title: authorization: handle strdup failures in realm file parser
body: This prevents a NULL ptr deferencing if strdup failed.

title: Files larger than the maximum size_t are cut off silently
body:
(This is about revision e380a8c.)
Excuse me if I am mistaken, but it seems that the length of a file delivered using sendfile is implicitly capped by the capacity of size_t.

common/lwan-serve-files.c:778

``` c++
lwan_sendfile(request, file_fd, from, (size_t)to);
```

to is an off_t which seems to be the correct type for a file size. On systems where sizeof(size_t) < sizeof(off_t) the truncating cast makes it impossible to deliver file ranges longer than SIZE_T_MAX correctly. On 32-bit systems SIZE_T_MAX is typically 2^32-1 which would be an archaic file size limit.

title: Many conversion and overflow warnings with -Wconversion
body:
When GCC 4.8 compiles a064623 with "-Wall -Wextra -Wshadow -Wconversion -pedantic -std=gnu99" for AMD64 there are many warnings. More than 200 of them are about integer conversions. Some of them are bugs, for example in murmur3.c:316:

MurmurHash3_x64_128(keyptr, len, 0xdeadbeef, hash);

len ist size_t, but the second parameter is declared as int.
You should consider using the correct integer types consistently and/or adding appropriate casts.

title: Unknown escape sequence: '\%'
body: When GCC 4.8 compiles a064623 with "-Wall -Wextra -Wshadow -Wconversion -pedantic -std=gnu99" there are many warnings. One of the warnings is about the nonsensical escape sequence \% in a string literal in lwan-response.c.

title: How to Pass data in lwan_set_url_map
Make lwan compilable on Ubuntu 12.04
body:
Changes as below:
- Modify the library order to as to ensure that pthread-related
  `undefined reference`s are all accounted for. Similarly, move
  zlib references to the end. This was an issue for both `lwan`
  and `freegeoip` binaries, so fix only those.
- `sqlite3_errstr` remains undefined even after rearranging the
  order of library linking. This could be an issue with `v3.8.3` of
  sqlite3 I am using, but not completely sure. Modifying it to
  `sqlite3_errmsg` works in a backward-compatible manner.

The system that I am working with looks like follows:

``` shell
vaibhav@sahadev:~/lwan|master⇒  uname -a
Linux sahadev 3.8.0-29-generic #42~precise1-Ubuntu SMP Wed Aug 14 16:19:23 UTC 2013 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
vaibhav@sahadev:~/lwan|master⇒  lsb_release -a
No LSB modules are available.
Distributor ID: Ubuntu
Description:    Ubuntu 12.04.3 LTS
Release:    12.04
Codename:   precise
```

title: HTTP Basic Authorization should store the base64-encoded username/password in Base64
body: Or a secure hash of it. This is so the Base64 decoding process is executed only once while the authorization cache is cold.

title: Upload File(s) to Gist fails while using Remote-WSL connection
body:
**Describe the bug**
Attempts to Upload File(s) to Gist fails while using a Remote-WSL connection with the following message...

Error running command gistpad.uploadFileToGist: Running the contributed command: 'gistpad.uploadFileToGist' failed.. This is likely caused by the extension that contributes gistpad.uploadFileToGist.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. From VSCode running on Windows 10 w/ Windows Subsystem for Linux; command pallete -> Remote-WSL: New Window
2. Open the GistPad tab in the activity bar
3. Right click on a Gist, and chose Upload File(s)
4. Select any file from the pop-up file chooser
5. Error encountered

**Expected behavior**
Expect file to upload to Gist.

**Screenshots**
Error running command gistpad.uploadFileToGist: Running the contributed command: 'gistpad.uploadFileToGist' failed.. This is likely caused by the extension that contributes gistpad.uploadFileToGist.

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - Windows 10 20H2, WSL w/ Ubuntu-20.04
 - VS Code Version 1.55.2
 - GistPad Version 0.2.8
 - Remote - WSL extension Version 0.54.6

title: Add optional frontmatter snippet to new notes.
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, when clicking on the calendar icon in VSCode, a new markdown file is autogenerated and added to a configurable directory.

The filename is the current date, and the same date is used to populate the first header in the generated file:

**`2021-03-25.md`**
```md 
# March 25, 2021
```

I really like how one click gets you to immediately writing a new note for the specific date.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

I would like it if it was possible to change the generated content in the markdown file to include some basic frontmatter metadata so that it would look something like this:

**`2021-03-25.md`**
```md 
---
title: March 25, 2021
---
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I can just write in the required frontmatter text every time, but it kind of goes against the spirit of clicking on the button and immediately getting to writing.

**Additional context**
I've been using this app to integrate with the blogging side of docusaurus. 
It'd be great to generate entirely new blog posts just from the click of a single button.

title: Add Extension to Open VSX registry https://open-vsx.org/
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
No

**Describe the solution you'd like**
To be able to access gistpad  from Gitpod

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Add Extension to Open VSX registry https://open-vsx.org/

N/A

title: Insert Snippet at the Cursor Position
body:
Opening snippets in a separate tab is annoying as I do a lot of work with snippets. I can see some of the snippets extensions are inserting the snippets directly in to the cursor position. 

I like to request the same functionality in the gistpad too.  You can bring up some setting or a keyboard shortcut to search and insert the gist at the cursor position rather than opening it in a separate tab.

title: Feature request: GitHub repo link handler URI scheme for opening repositories
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Opening a public repo with GistPad to read code could be faster. 

The current process is:
1. `⌘+Shift+P`
2. `> GistPad: Open Repository`
3. Type repository name

As a point of comparison, github1s is a very fast way to view a GitHub repo's codebase from inside a web-based version of Visual Studio Code, e.g. [https://github**1s**.com/codespaces-contrib/gistpad](https://github1s.com/codespaces-contrib/gistpad) – you just add `1s` to the URL in your browser tab.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
If there was a "Open in VSCode" button on GitHub repo pages, I would click that button often – specifically for reading/searching code quickly. The simplest way to enable that would be a link handler URI scheme.

A URI scheme would be broadly useful. For example, it would let `README.md` for boilerplate repos add a `Open in VSCode` button, which would be faster than pasting `git clone` into your terminal and opening the repo in a local folder 

I would be happy to make a "Open in VSCode" button as a very simple Chrome extension (it would just add a button with the link in a good spot on repository pages). 

I do have access to Codespaces, but I don't currently use it because for writing code, I would rather use my own editor/environment.

title: Ability to move gist from secret to public and vice versa
body: It would be great if we can right click on gist and select something like `Make public` if current gist is secret, and `Make secret` if current gist is private

title: Open gist in GitHub in file toolbar
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
When I need to checkout how the gist looks like on GitHub for the gist that I am currently working on in editor, I need to search for it again in GistPad, if gists are not sorted by update time (if not changing gists but just opened few of them, sort is irrelevant).

**Describe the solution you'd like**
File is already open in the editor, why not having Open Gist icon in file toolbar   ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/85767/107116392-2e2a8b80-6873-11eb-9bb9-62e730b5077c.png)



**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Setting `gistpad.openRepositoryFileInBrowser` hotkey but that is not ideal as operation is not so important to hijack hotkey.

**Additional context**

<details><summary>image</summary> 


![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/85767/107116377-0a674580-6873-11eb-8560-1179c85d7209.png)

</details>

title: Allow changing destination directory name of Cloned Gist Repositories
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Clone to Repository saves as the gist GUID which can make it hard to identify

**Describe the solution you'd like**
When choosing "Clone Repository", offer a popup to name the repository folder in the target rather than the GUID it is typically assigned. This behavior could be toggled by a preference variable

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Clone and then rename afterwards, however this is less desirable to the workflow

title: [Enterprise] Can't use token with enterprise GitHub server
body:
**Describe the bug**
I've overridden the apiUrl
`    "gistpad.apiUrl": "https://mygitserver.com/api/v3",`
But when trying to signin (either by the command pallette or through the button on the top left)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3136012/104459496-7a0c4c80-55b5-11eb-9f45-45c975dae39f.png)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to Settings.
2. Search for Gisthub
3. Modify **Gistpad: Api URL** and save
4. Click on Command+Shift+P and select Gistpad: Sign In...

**Expected behavior**
Since I'm overriding the apiUrl - no need to take me to 
**https://vscode-auth.github.com/authorize/?callbackUri=vscode://vscode.github-authentication/did-authenticate%253FwindowId%253D1&scope=gist%20repo&state=[unique-id]&responseType=code&authServer=https://github.com**
and instead skip this step and just expect a Github token.

**Screenshots**

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - VS Code Version [v1.52.1]
 - GistPad Version [v0.2.1]

**Additional context**
Add any other context about the problem here.

title: Publish this extension to https://open-vsx.org
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I'm using VSCodium and want to install this extension via *Extensions* from inside VSCodium

**Describe the solution you'd like**
VSCodium uses the extension index form [open-vsx.org](https://open-vsx.org) as described in their [docs](https://github.com/VSCodium/vscodium/blob/master/DOCS.md#extensions--marketplace). It would be great, if I can just installed it from inside VSCodium and it works.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Installing *.vsix* directly. Unfortunately the Github login process from within the extension is then somehow not working 🤷‍♂️

title: How to disconnect and reconnect to a different Github account?
body:
I accidentally connected GistPad to the wrong Github account and I can't figure out how to remove the authentication so that I can connect to the correct account. I tried uninstalling and reinstalling, but the token must be stored elswhere as GistPad just reconnected to the wrong account.

Raising as a bug because I believe uninstalling Gistpad should remove the credentials, and therefore prompt for authentication when reinstalled.

It would be useful if there was an option to "logout" GistPad available from the command palette.

title: I frequently have to sign in
body:
**Describe the bug**

Since maybe few months back, I need to re-sign in very often. Previously I never had to do that. I don't know when/why it happens.

**Expected behavior**

To never resign on single machine when token is valid.


**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - VS Code Version 1.50.1
 - GistPad Version 0.1.12

title: Need ability to diff the gist changes before committing them.
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently when editing gists via gistpad, I cannot diff the changes before committing them.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Would be great if somehow `source control` tab (highlighted below) would also show the proposed changes to gists.   

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2327905/100488143-6eaeb000-3132-11eb-9d11-c3794662b809.png)

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
AFAIK, currently there is no way to diff any proposed gist changes prior to committing them.

**Additional context**
None.

title: gistpad.playgrounds.autoSave should default to false
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Out of the box, the setting `gistpad.playgrounds.autoSave` defaults to `true`. Many a times, this leads to accidental edits being persisted to the github gists. 

I now have to visit `gist.github.com` to see the gist's revision history and figure out how to undo these accidental changes.

Most of the times, I simply wish to open my gists for reading/viewing only.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
The setting `gistpad.playgrounds.autoSave` should default to `true`. Let the users choose to explicitly persist changes (if any).

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Another alternative is to open gists in a read-only mode by default.

title: Pin/favorite a repository to keep it at the top of the repository list
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I use a small number of repositories for daily note-taking (non-work, work) and having to pick them out of the repository list can be frustrating, especially when I have a lot of repositories tracked from organizations which come before my github username, 

e.g.
- Acme/somerepo
- ...many Acme repos...
- taddison/garage-wiki (the repo I want at the top)

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like to specify one or more repos to appear at the top of the repository list.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I could change my GitHub username to be aaaddison 😅?  And then name any daily repos to be named such that they'll always appear at the top.

**Additional context**
Minimal example with the SQLChecks repo pushing down my note-taking repo:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2743558/100384227-a8c26980-2fed-11eb-9f83-c00c3a23c147.png)

title: How long do you expect the token be valid?
body:
I am running vscode 1.51.1 on several PCs.

What I found is that the token are somehow lost after vscode restart/upgrade/OS restart. 

I haven't figured out the stable way to reproduce.

Is anyone bother by the similar?

Thanks!

``` vscode
Version: 1.51.1
Commit: e5a624b788d92b8d34d1392e4c4d9789406efe8f
Date: 2020-11-10T23:31:29.624Z
Electron: 9.3.3
Chrome: 83.0.4103.122
Node.js: 12.14.1
V8: 8.3.110.13-electron.0
OS: Linux x64 5.7.17-1rodete4-amd64
```

I am also using vscode's setting sync. Not sure if it is related.

title: Keyboard shortcuts
body:
(Sorry for opening 3 issues in quick succession! I just like this extension and can see it being a part of my workflow)

**Describe the bug**
There is a big list of keyboard shortcuts (filter the list by `gistpad`), which are all unassigned by default.

I wanted to rename gists using F2, like you can with files in the explorer.
There's a command for this, `gistpad.renameFile`.
When I run this though, I get the warning, `Cannot read property 'path' of undefined`.
I've tried focusing different things in case it requires a specific 'When' case.

As far as I know, this actually applies to all of them, so perhaps it's just not fully implemented :smile:

**To Reproduce**
1. Open keyboard shortcuts
2. Filter the list by `gistpad`
3. Assign shortcut to any of these
4. Try using them.

**Expected behavior**
They should do carry out the specified action

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3299161/99573617-3d194480-29ce-11eb-9ab7-d7ac7f7e1af9.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3299161/99573669-486c7000-29ce-11eb-9167-bbc982272765.png)

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - VS Code Version: 1.51.1
 - GistPad Version 0.1.9

title: Ability to change scratch note naming format
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Scratch notes are named with the current date in a format such as `November 19, 2019.md`.
I like to write in here, then move to a 'real' gist with the same name (and an appropriate tag) when I'm sure I won't scrap it.
Personally, I'd prefer not to have a comma in the filename, and be something like YYYY-MM-DD for sorting (if I'd need to).

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I'd like to be able to specify the naming convention.
Sorry I can't suggest the optional scheme, maybe someone can weigh in.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
Renaming files manually. It might be easier if you could use the `F2` shortcut in the explorer sidebar, but you would still have to type.

title: Extra revisions with no changes
body:
**Describe the bug**
Saving a file with no changes still makes a commit with no changes.

**To Reproduce**
1. Have a gist note.
2. Add some text then remove it again
3. Save the note

**Expected behavior**
As there were no changes, don't commit and push another revision.

**Screenshots**
This is how it looks in GitHub proper.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3299161/99564242-17863e00-29c2-11eb-81a7-a099cfc22b42.png)

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**
 - VS Code Version: 1.51.1
 - GistPad Version 0.1.9

**Additional context**
Maybe the ability to disable this this is a feature request? Seems unlikely anybody would want this behaviour though.

title: Bump yargs-parser from 13.1.1 to 13.1.2
body:
Bumps [yargs-parser](https://github.com/yargs/yargs-parser) from 13.1.1 to 13.1.2.
Changelog

Sourced from yargs-parser's changelog.

15.0.0 (2019-10-07)

Features

  • rework collect-unknown-options into unknown-options-as-args, providing more comprehensive functionality (ef771ca)

BREAKING CHANGES

  • rework collect-unknown-options into unknown-options-as-args, providing more comprehensive functionality

14.0.0 (2019-09-06)

Bug Fixes

  • boolean arrays with default values (#185) (7d42572)
  • boolean now behaves the same as other array types (#184) (17ca3bd)
  • eatNargs() for 'opt.narg === 0' and boolean typed options (#188) (c5a1db0)
  • maybeCoerceNumber now takes precedence over coerce return value (#182) (2f26436)
  • take into account aliases when appending arrays from config object (#199) (f8a2d3f)

Features

  • add configuration option to "collect-unknown-options" (#181) (7909cc4)
  • maybeCoerceNumber() now takes into account arrays (#187) (31c204b)

BREAKING CHANGES

  • unless "parse-numbers" is set to "false", arrays of numeric strings are now parsed as numbers, rather than strings.
  • we have dropped the broken "defaulted" functionality; we would like to revisit adding this in the future.
  • maybeCoerceNumber now takes precedence over coerce return value (#182)

title: Collapse showcase by default
body:
As cool as it is, I personally don't use the showcase tab all that often and would like to have it collapsed by default.
Perhaps a simply entry in `settings.json`?

title: update categories in package.json (#178)
body: This PR fixes Issue #178 and adds gistpad to Data Science, Snippets, and Visualization extension categories.

title: Add gistpad to Data Science and Visualization extension categories
body:
as a vscode marketplace SEO enhancement since this extension ships with some data viz playground gists for data scientists to try.

VSCode v1.48.0 and vscode marketplace now allow to find extensions by category, with new Data Science and Visualization categories added recently. See: https://code.visualstudio.com/updates/v1_48#_extensions-overflow-menu-cleanup

In order to enable this SEO enhancement, we just need to update categories in `package.json`. I would also suggest we add Snippets since gists can be viewed as short code snippets in loose terms.

Proposed changes to `package.json`:

```
"categories": [
    "Data Science",
    "Other",
    "Snippets",
    "Visualization"
  ]
```

What those category filters look like in extensions view panel:

![vega-viewer-data-science](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/656833/90313781-c8b59d80-ded4-11ea-9ed2-f6ac57cac543.png)
``

title: Support for snowpack
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I'd like to use some more exotic packages and currently there's a limited set of packages available through cdnjs. I know you can paste in urls from the likes of jsdelivr and unkpkg but I'm just not sure how to use some packages like this. I think they have to be designed with these services in mind.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
A solution could be to use snowpack which is developed for "Unbundled Development" which is something that gistpad seems to be designed for.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I've tried jsdeliver and unpkg as a possible workaround.

In general really love the approach of Gistpad, it's an amazing and ambitious extension!

title: Feature Request: Copy File "latest" Link
body:
With a Gist, if you remove a particular section of the URI, it will always point to the "latest" file, it would be nice to have the context menu include this option as "Copy Latest URL"
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15258962/89001985-c33f3d00-d2b0-11ea-936d-b7847c604ddb.png)


Example: https://gist.githubusercontent.com/JustinGrote/866536458bfa097cb18a4b82181e5f16/raw/**1b587a334ece5453353529549a726fe3cf392edb**/PoshAnywhere.ps1

Remove the section between the two stars and it will always point to the latest commit, good for install scripts and other items where you want the user to always use the latest version.

title: GitHub API rate limit consumed
body:
GistPad seems to send out a lot of requests to the GitHub API. I'm pretty sure this is causing language server updates for the rust-analyzer extension (which uses a single request to the GitHub API for that) to fail until the rate limit resets.

For example, just loading the extension already sends out 12 requests:
![unknown](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/827762/87963023-637ab200-cab8-11ea-9d2f-90a54c8c8cf7.png)
And it didn't stop there, although I didn't investigate exactly when it sends out more requests—I assume you know all about that.

I have now signed in, which makes it use the token for its requests and thus bypass rate limits, but this shouldn't have been possible anyway.

**Expected behavior**
Since this seems to be enough to use up the rate limit over time, it'd be nice if it at least warned that that's happening when you're not signed in, or somehow cached the results or perhaps even blocked entirely until signed in?

**Desktop:**
 - VS Code Version v1.47.2
 - GistPad Version v0.1.8

title: version 0.1.8 will suppress string autocompletion in Markdown
body:
**Describe the bug**
When this extension GistPad of version 0.1.8 and/or the extension `:emojisense:` of a recent version is enabled, string autocompletion in Markdown will be suppressed.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:

0. Make sure GistPad of version 0.1.8 and `:emojisense:` of any version disabled or uninstalled
1. Enable autocompletion in Markdown with below settings
   ```json
   {
       "editor.quickSuggestions": {
           "comments": true,
           "other": true,
           "strings": true
       },
       "[markdown]": {
           "editor.quickSuggestions": true
       },
   }
   ```
2. Open any Markdown file, and the autocompletion works as the first screenshot shows, where GistPad is of version 0.1.7
3. Install or enable GistPad of version 0.1.8. Alternatively, install or enable `:emojisense:`
4. The autocompletion is now suppressed and broken, like in the second gif screenshot. You can see the string completion is suppressed almost immediately

**Expected behavior**
Autocompletion should remain intact and completions should not be suppressed.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13913131/87871814-42499100-c9e6-11ea-9f40-e4a07ae031ca.png)
![Jul-19-2020 17-39-14](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13913131/87872283-aa4da680-c9e9-11ea-8ba1-d75f43b3e547.gif)

**Desktop (please complete the following information):**

- VS Code Version v1.47.2
- GistPad Version v0.1.8

**Additional context**

1. I rely on autocompletion heavily when writing Markdown
1. Since `:emojisense:` is shipped along with this extension and can also be the culprit, it is mentioned too
3. Annoyingly, the extension "GitHub Pull Requests and Issues" can also be the culprit under some circumstances.

title: Ability to generate a git.io shortURLs for gists
body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
I have been using gists a lot lately and GistPad helps me manage all that without leaving the editor. I embed these gist URLs in my blog posts and reference them at several places. With the GUIDs embedded into these gist URLs, they tend to be very long. I am, at the moment, using git.io to shorten these urls and then embed into my articles. 

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Having a context menu option to "Copy GitHub short URL" will be quite useful.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I am using a [PowerShell module](https://github.com/rchaganti/PSGitIo) that I published for this purpose.

title: Get "TypeError: Cannot read property 'sha' of undefined" when click just created wiki link
body:
**Describe the bug**
Get "TypeError: Cannot read property 'sha' of undefined" when click just created `[[wiki link]]`.

title: Add support for inter-wiki links
body:
Currently, GistPad wikis allow you to create [`[[links]]`](https://github.com/vsls-contrib/gistpad#links) amongst markdown pages in the same repo, but there isn't support for defining inter-wiki links. Adding this would allow users to maintain n-number of separate repos and/or have personal/team/community wikis that contain interconnected knowledge (which is super cool!).

As a starting point of view, we could implement support for [inter-wiki links](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interwiki_links), where the wiki identfier is the name of a GitHub repo, or the ID of a gist (e.g. `[[lostintangent/foam-workspace:Todo]]`).

title: Fix gitCredentialFill hanging when it tries to prompt credentials in execSync
body:
**This PR fixes Issue #153**
> The issue mentions Ubuntu  18.04, but I have only tested this on Windows 10. I can setup an Ubuntu machine when I have more time later to confirm this fixes the command on there also, but I don't have access to a MacOS machine that can test this currently.

**Description of the PR**:
This changes `execGitCredentialFill` to set the `GIT_ASKPASS` environment variable to the `askpass-empty.sh` script from the VSCode git extension when calling `execSync`. By making AskPass use `askpass-empty.sh`, the credentials prompt should be skipped when credentials are not set and return an empty string for the the password. So, it should make `execGitCredentialFill` a readonly function instead of getting hung when `git credential fill` tries to ask for credentials.

**Additional context**:
When `git credential fill` is executed and there are not any credentials, it tries to request credentials from the user. Unless the AskPass tool is configured correctly, `execSync` gets stuck when there are no credentials, because it is waiting on input, but `execSync` didn't get any output yet. So they both just sit there waiting on a response from each other, without knowing each other is waiting.

title: Fix git credential fill command
body:
Related to my question in #68, I figured out why this was not working for me. There was a bug in the `git credential fill` input so I removed the leading whitespaces which lead to the command not being properly executed.

When using
```sh
protocol=https
  host=github.com

```
as input for `git credential fill`, it simply queries the first entry in e.g. the macOS keychain that matches `protocol=https`, the `host=github.com` part is simply ignored.

title: CodeTours recorded within Tutorial Playgrounds do not play upon loading Tutorial.
body:
This appears to be due to the way the tour.json file is saved when recording CodeTours, which is in the root folder of the playground. This works for Playgrounds, but not Tutorial Playgrounds. 

Further, this behaviour is different from the Learning MobX Showcase Tutorial which saves a tour.json file within each numbered directory of the Tutorial Playground.

When the recorded CodeTour is altered to contain tour.json files within each step's directory (and the file references appropriately corrected in the tour.json file) the CodeTour plays as expected.

To reproduce:
1. Create a new playground and convert it to a tutorial.
2. Add first step directory and code file, e.g. "1/script.js"
3. Record a CodeTour in "script.js"
4. Reload the Tutorial Playground.

title: Unable to open Gist file with backslash in the filename
body:
**Environment:** 
Windows 10
VSCode 1.42.1
GistPad 0.0.55

**Error Message:**
`Unable to open 'bat.json': Unable to read file 'gist://2ee56db181266c4cb39c4f482e1277e6/snippets\bat.json' (TypeError: Cannot read property 'truncated' of undefined).`

**Steps to Reproduce:**

```
1. Create a text file with some content either locally or directly in the Gist.
2. Refresh GistPad so that the file resides in both locations.
3. Check that you can view the file.

Try steps 4.x or 5.x

4.1 Rename the file locally by adding a backslash to the file name.
4.2 Refresh GistPad.
4.4 Check that the file was updated in the Gist
4.5. Try to view or rename the file locally.

OR

5.1 Rename the file in the Gist by adding a backslash to the file name.
5.2 Refresh GistPad.
5.2 Check that the file was updated locally and is visible in the tree.
5.3. Try to view or rename the file locally.
```

I ran across this today when trying to view a file from a Gist that stores configuration files.  The Gist files are named by prefacing their filename with their path, and on a Windows system that includes a backslash.

If I go into the Gist and change or remove the backslash character it works. If I rename a local file from a Gist by adding a backslash it does rename the file and push it back into the Gist but after that all other attempts to read or rename the file again to remove the backslash fail.

title: 👋 Feedback Wanted: What are you using GistPad for?
body:
Hi! 👋 As part of building out the GistPad experience, we’re very keen to understand what folks are using it for (e.g. maintaining your personal [code snippets](https://twitter.com/marcduiker/status/1206317447483207681?s=21), [collaborating with others](https://twitter.com/uncoded_ls/status/1213975978516586497?s=21), building [interactive playgrounds](https://twitter.com/lostintangent/status/1207718123241033728?s=21), [creating tutorials](https://twitter.com/lostintangent/status/1228780570932498432?s=21) for an online class), to help inform our backlog prioritization, and identify further areas of improvement.

If you’re currently using GistPad (or plan to soon!), it would be extremely helpful if you could share a quick description of your use case, as well as what would be the top thing(s) we could do to improve your workflow. Thanks!

title: Look into interop with Memo
body: [Memo](https://usememo.com) is a note taking app that persists its data to gist. We should also investigate whether there’s anything needed to ensure GistPad can interoperate with it.

title: Add support for multi-level directories
body: Currently, you can organize your gist files into directories, but only a single-level. The notion of gist directories are meant to extend the value of gists, not to replace repos, and so I'm not too sure how valuable it would be to support multi-level directories. That said, I want to track this limitation in order to get feedback from folks, and help inform the prioritization of this work.

title: Add functionality for viewing forks of Gist
body:
Allows user to right click on a Gist and view all forks, or get an error toast if it hasn't been forked yet.
Fixes https://github.com/vsls-contrib/gistpad/issues/98

Additional todo: 
1. Change Quickpick menu to include username of person who forked the Gist. 
2. Investigate whether it's possible to determine if a given Gist is a fork of another Gist.

title: Allow duplicating gist files
body: Currently, we allow you to duplicate gists, which creates a new gist, seeded with the contents of another gist. Additionally, we allow you to copy the contents of a file from one gist to another (as well as copy local files into gists). However, we don’t provide a one-click way to simply duplicate a file within a gist, much like you can with local files in VS Code. To address this, we should add a “Duplicate File” command to file nodes in the Gist tree, which will create a new file in the same gist, and using the same contents as the selected file.

title: Allow saving a temporary playground to a gist
body: We just introduced the ability to create a “temporary playground”, which allows creating playgrounds that aren’t persisted to gists. However, it’s possible that someone would initially create a temporary playground, but then later decide that they want to save it. To support this, we should provide a way to create a Gist from the current temporary playground.

title: Are JavaScript modules compiled or run natively?

title: Crate a completion provider for suggesting gist file names in certain file types (e.g. HTML)
body: In order to make it easier to reference relative files within a playground’s gist, we should explore registering a completion provider, that suggests the names of other files in the same gist, and is triggered when you’re typing URLs in certain file types (e.g. in HTML files).

title: Allow opening playgrounds from GitHub repos
body: Currently, GistPad operates entirely on Gists as its backing storage. However, more complex playgrounds may benefit from being stored in a repo, since that would allow them to use directories, create PRs, etc. As a result, we should explore extending the “Open Gist” command to accept GitHub repo URLs, in addition to Gist URLs.

title: [wip][playground][refactor]: refactor the playground render piece for reuse
body:
[wip] The PR refactors the code around the rendering of the playground preview with intent to reuse it in the preview server. We need this server for security boundaries in VSO. (and potentially the ability to embed playgrounds or host them e.g. `https://gispad.com/lostintangent/{id}` which should open interesting use case scenarios).

Had to unwrap some circular dependencies so the PR becomes slightly bigger than intended. After refactoring we have the `renderPlaygroundHtml` class that accepts a `gist` and renders the resulting HTML as a string(including adding libraries and transpile code if needed).

title: Add a “Split Bottom” playground layout mode
body: We currently support the following playground layouts: grid, preview, split left, split right and split top. However, we don’t support “split bottom”, where the preview window occupies the bottom half of the editor height, and the three editor windows occupy the top half. In order to provide users and playgrounds with more options, we should provide the “split bottom” layout as well.

title: Playground outside auth
body:
This PR adds the ability for new users (who have not signed in) to start a quick playground. The "temp playgrounds" are created under [the gistpad account](https://gist.github.com/gistpad). Once the user signs in, they can fork this temporary playground into their account. The goal is to make it easier for users to try out the playground experience, and then gradually onboard to regular authenticated users.

This PR needs some more work before it can be merged, for example
- [ ] alert user that saving the gist is not saving it to their accounts, and prompt them to sign in
- [ ] one click action to fork when the user signs in
- [x] there's a "description undefined" error that shows up right after the playground is created
- [ ] default templates are not available if the user is not authenticated

I'm creating this WIP PR to see if the implementation seems correct (~there are some state changes involved~, not anymore with the in-memory FS)

(also fyi, depends on #104)

title: [ui][activity bar]: add Gist kind icons

The PR

- adds Gist type icons to the Activity Bar tree for convenience:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1478800/72318829-3d301180-3652-11ea-8b31-8e91ffa0228e.png)

- adds the `treeIcons` boolean setting to disable the icons in the tree.

title: Display an MRU list for playground libraries
body: When you add a library to a playground, we currently display the complete, alphabetical list of available libraries. However, it’s likely that users will use the same libraries over and over again, and therefore, we should explore displaying an MRU list at the top of the library list, to allow quickly picking your favorite library, in addition to being able to search for one.

title: Allow creating playgrounds without logging in
body:
In order to create playgrounds, you need to first authenticate with GitHub. This is because playground files are written to gists, and therefore, those gists need to be associated with a specific user.

However, some users may simply want to create ephemeral playgrounds that allow them to explore an idea quickly, and then move on. In these situations, persisting the playground might not be useful, and therefore, needing to sign in could feel a little heavyweight.

To better enable the use of playgrounds, we should explore allowing playground creation, without needing to sign in.

title: [mobx] `observableArray.sort()` error
body:
```js
[mobx] `observableArray.sort()` will not update the array in place. Use `observableArray.slice().sort()` to suppress this warning and perform the operation on a copy, or `observableArray.replace(observableArray.slice().sort())` to sort & update in place (at Proxy.sort (/Users/xxx/.vscode-insiders/extensions/vsls-contrib.gistfs-0.0.43/out/prod/extension.js:88120:21))
```

title: Enable using jsDelivr as the playground library CDN
body: Currently, we allow searching for playground libraries using CDNJS, which provides a fixed set of packages. We should explore using jsDelivr instead, or offering it as an alternative, since it provides an entire reverse proxy on top of NPM, and therefore, would have many more libraries than CDNJS.

title: Allow viewing the forks associated with a gist
body: Currently, there's no way to determine whether a gist was forked from another gist and/or whether a gist has been forked by others. We should explore how to visualize this data in the `Gists` view, so that for example, devs can see who is using their playgrounds/gists as "templates" to explore their own derivations/ideas on top of it.

title: Allow migrating gists to GitHub repos
body: Currently, we allow you to export playgrounds to CodePen, which make it easy to share them with the broader web developer community. Additionally, we allow you to clone a gist locally, which means you could easily create a new repo and push the Gist's code to it. However, in order to make it simpler to "migrate" a gist to a repo (e.g. because you want to work on it with other people, because you want to enable GitHub Pages for static hosting), we should add an `Export to GitHub` command that automatically creates the new repo (or allows you to select an existing one) and handles committing the gist code to it.

title: Add the ability to view the compiled code for playground languages
body: Currently, playgrounds allow you to write TypeScript, Pug, SCSS and Less, and the code is automatically compiled to JavaScript, HTML and CSS on-the-fly. However, in order to enable users to learn new languages and/or see how these preprocessed languages work, we should introduce a way to toggle a view that shows the resulting code when compiling TypeScript, Pug, SCSS and Less.

title: Allow selecting a starred gist when pasting a gist into the editor
body: Currently, we add the `Paste Gist File` command to the editor's context menu, which allows you to quickly paste the contents of a gist file into your open document. However, this command only allows you to select one of your own gists, not a starred gist. As a workaround, you could right-click the starred gist file in the `Gists` explorer and select `Copy File Contents`, but it would be a bit more ergonomic if the `Paste Gist File` command in the editor allowed you to select a starred file directly.

title: [Feature name]: testing Live Share Spaces branch broadcast
body:
What needs to be done:

1. Implement a.
2. Implement b.
2. Implement c.

title: Provide an indication of new/unseen gists from followed users
body: When you follow a user, you can see all of their gists, and sort them by updated time. However, we don’t currently provide an indication of gists that are “new” to you, and therefore, make it easier to “subscribe” to a user. This could make it possible to follow online tutorials/classes, and be notified of new material/challenges/etc.

title: Allow starring gists from followed users
body: When you follow a user, we currently allow you to open/clone/fork their gists, but we don’t expose an option to star their gists. This would be really valuable, to enable users to “favorite” specific gists from users they’re following, without needing to go to GitHub.com in order to do it.

title: Add a “Follow Me in GistPad” deep link/badge
body: GistPad allows users to follow each other, and stay up to date with the gists/playgrounds they’re building. In order to simplify the following process, and enable devs to advertise their GistPad presence in docs/etc. we should introduce a “deep link” URL and badge, that allows users to automate the process of launching VS Code and following the respective user.

title: Allow referencing external libraries that are written in other languages
body: GistPad allows you to add external references to script and stylesheet libraries, and it automatically injects them into the preview page. However, it assumes these references point to JavaScript and CSS files, and therefore, doesn’t attempt to compile them before injecting them. In order to support reusable “Gist templates”, that could include SCSS and TypeScript, we should introduce library compilation, in addition to just playground file compilation.

title: Add support for defining/using SCSS partials/modules
body:
GistPad playgrounds already allow you to use SCSS as your style sheet language, however, your stylesheets can’t currently @import/@use other modules. In order to allow you to define custom partials and then use them in your stylesheets, we should explore defining a [custom module importer](https://sass-lang.com/documentation/js-api#importer) when we compile SCSS.

_Note that the equivalent behavior doesn’t appear to be possible with Pug or TypeScript, so our primary reusability/template story should likely be based around external library references._

title: collapse gist comments by default
body:
showing the comments on gist open could be distractive specially for a long list of comments.

if u want to keep it as dynamic as possible, we can use an option to show/hide them instead.

title: Create new gist\playground if the filesystem url is gist://new or gist://playground.
Detect GitHub Enterprise URL from environment variable
body: Currently, we allow users to specify their GitHub Enterprise URL via a VS Code setting, but we should also allow this to be set via an environment variable, in order to provide better interop with existing tools (e.g. the Hub and [Gist](https://github.com/defunkt/gist) CLIs).

title: Support SSO with the Hub and Gist CLIs
body: Currently, we support SSO with the Git CLI, which enables GistPad to authenticate automatically if the user has already signed in with GitHub and has a token with gist permissions. However, we should also add SSO support for the Hub and [Gist](https://github.com/defunkt/gist) CLIs as well. That way, we can minimize the getting started experience for new users, that may be using other Gist-related tools.

Split out auth across desktop and browser
body: Add an abstraction for the sign in flow so that the clicking signin can trigger a browser based auth flow.

title: Re-open playground preview after restarting VS Code
body:
Currently, if you have a playground open and then restart VS Code, the playground files (e.g. index.html) and WebView remain open, but the preview window isn’t properly hooked up. As a result, the user has to re-open the playground in order to start working on it again.

To make this experience smoother, we should detect the restart and then re-initialize the playground automatically.

title: Allow pasting images into HTML files
body: We currently contribute the “Paste Screenshot” command, to make it easy to upload/insert images from your clipboard and into markdown files. However, to improve the playground experience, we should also allow this command to be run in HTML files, so that local images can be easily used in playgrounds, without the user needing to manually upload it to the Gist or an image hosting service.

title: Add support for other playground languages
body:
Currently, you can create playgrounds using the following languages: HTML/Pug, CSS/SCSS/Less, and JavaScript/TypeScript. In all cases, the code is compiled as needed, as you type, without the user needing to do anything. This makes it really easy to visually iterate on code, using whichever languages you’re most productive with.

In order to continue supporting other developer preferences, I’d love to hear feedback about which additional languages would be useful to have. For example: [Stylus](https://codepen.io/jh3y/pen/rNawvYm), [Haml](https://codepen.io/vcurd/pen/VwYbEom), Elm, PureScript, Vue single file components, Svelte, etc. I’ll also continue to survey the CodePen ecosystem to see what folks are using in practice, to make sure that GistPad playgrounds provide strong interop with the community.

title: Allow specifying external stylesheet references in playground.json
body: Currently, you can add playground references to external JavaScript libraries, by adding them to the “libraries” property of the playground’s playground.json manifest file. However, we should also allow specifying external stylesheet references as well, via a new “styles” (or “stylesheets”?) property. Just like the existing libraries support, we should also enable a rich integration with CDNJS so that it’s easy to add commonly used stylsheets (e.g. font awesome).

title: Add a “Send to CodePen” command for exporting playgrounds
body: We currently allow opening pens that have been exported to Gists, and to complete the CodePen interop, we should add a way to “export” a GistPad playground to a CodePen pen. They’ve already got the [API](https://blog.codepen.io/documentation/api/prefill/) for this, and it would enable devs to work on a playground locally, and then “migrate” it to CodePen for sharing.

title: Bad Credentials in Git Enterprise integration - can't login
body:
Hey.
As suggested, I updated the settings for GitAPI:
```"gistpad.apiUrl": "https://git.myOrg.com/api/v3"```

title: [editor]: add `Paste Screenshot` command
body: The PR: 1. Implements `Paste Screenshot` command (using abstractions infrastructure in anticipation of the serverless experience). By default, the screenshot is uploaded to the gist as a `.png` file: ![paste-screenshot](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1478800/70382701-9a7ac980-1914-11ea-9fb0-6e55424e2e54.gif) 2. Contributes settings: - Contributes the `Gistpad: Paste Screenshot Type` setting that alters the behaviour to `base64`-embed the screenshot instead of uploading as a file. - Contributes the `Gistpad: Paste Screenshot Output` setting that allows switching between `Markdown`(default)/`HTML` for image markup (e.g. `![img](link)` vs ``). 3. Adds the `super + shift + v` command for the command above. 3. Adds the `Paste Screenshot` context menu item.

title: This extension conflicts with the GitHub Gist Explorer extension.
body: According to my observations, if this extension is installed together with the extension GitHub Gist Explorer (k9982874.github-gist-explorer, https://github.com/k9982874/github-gist-explorer), then this causes the removal of the GitHub Gist Explorer. If you perform operations with gist using the GistPad extension and then restart VS Code, then GitHub Gist Explorer will be deleted. Apparently at the moment, these expansions are incompatible and cannot be installed together. Link to this problem: https://github.com/k9982874/github-gist-explorer/issues/21 .

title: Allow specifying multiple files when creating a Gist
body: When you create a Gist, we currently allow you to specify the name of the file to seed it with. However, in order to simplify the process of creating multi-file Gists, we should allow users to specify a comma-separated list of file names to seed the new Gist with.

title: Allow opening/creating a Gist within the current workspace
body: Currently, when you create/open a Gist, we open it as a new virtual workspace. This reloads VS Code, and prevents you from being able to easily work on a Gist alongside of another project. To address this, we should add an option to open/create a Gist as a series of “loose files”’within the current VS Code instance (without needing to reload).

title: Add Gist management view
body: In addition to allowing you to list your gists via #2, we should also add a tree view to easily manage your Gists visually (add/delete/open/star).

title: "org.freedesktop.secrets was not provided by any .service files" when doing GistFS: New Gist for the first time

After successfully installed GistFS from the market place, when the "GistFS: New Gist" command was run for the first time, VSCode prompted me with the following error message:
`org.freedesktop.secrets was not provided by any .service files`

After some googling, install the following package on my system solved it:
_gnome-keyring_

Perhaps it would help to include some pointer in the Getting Started section of the document / webpage that gnome-keyring is a dependency?

title: Allow creating secret Gists
body: Gists can be either public or secret. Many times, I want to create a secret Gist. It would be great if there was a command to create a secret Gist.

title: Ability to Group Github Gists
body:
Github Gist does not support folders. However, we can consider setting tags in the description of a Gist, which could be used to create a grouping in vscode.

An application like lepton appends `#thistag` to the description of the gist.

Suggestions:
Option 1: use [#tag1, #tag2] at the beginning of the description
Option 1: use #thistag1 appended at the end of the description of a gist

title: Introduce the notion of Gist “templates” to allow quickly creating new Gists
Prompt the user to fork, when they try to edit a Gist they don’t own
body: When you attempt to edit a Gist, we currently prompt you to authenticate if you haven’t already. However, if the currently opened Gist isn’t yours, then you won’t be able to edit it, regardless if you’re signed in or not. In order to make this flow more user-friendly, we should automatically detect it, and ask the user if they’d like to fork the currently opened Gist.

title: Allow listing your starred gists
body: Related to #2, but would present the list of Gists you’ve starred, not the ones you’ve created.

title: Allow listing your Gists
body: Instead of just creating a new gist, or opening one by ID, we should add a command to allow users to view all of their current Gists and then open one. That way, you don’t need to retrieve the Gist ID from the browser before you can begin editing it in VS Code.

title: Add a “Open in environment” command
body: Behind the scenes, a Gist is simply a GitHub repo, and therefore, we could enable “upgrading” from an editable Gist, to a fully compute-backed environment in VSO. This would allow running, debugging, etc. the code in the Gist, which might be valuable for quickly experimenting with some prototype/shared code.

title: application/json format.
body:
I've tested the JSON request for my project.

This is my dart client is at
https://github.com/bsjung/start_examples/blob/master/jwt/server/client.dart.

The header is set to {'Content-Type': "application/json"}.
But, the most client software appends to UTF encoding into HTTP header : [application/json; charset=utf-8].

The isMime() loose default is false.
Thus I think the loose default option should be set the true for client software.

-------------------------------------------------------------

 16   bool isMime(String type, {loose: false}) =>
 17       _request.headers[HttpHeaders.contentTypeHeader]
 18           .where((value) => loose ? value.contains(type) : value == type)
 19           .isNotEmpty;

------------------------------------------------------------

Benjamin Jung ( bsjung@gmail.com )

title: How to get the IP address of the client?
body: Is it possible to get the IP address of the client that has sent a request?

title: Start provides only indirect access to session data
body: Request class of start does not provide direct access to session data. Therefore accessing session data is unnecessary verbose due to the fact that we have to use input property of Request. ``` req.input.session['key'] = 'value'; ``` It would be more efficient to do it this way: ``` req.session['key'] = 'value'; ``` Therefore I propose to introduce the following getter to Request class to overcome unnecessary verbosity. ``` HttpSession get session => _request.session; ```

title: Concept of View is under-documented
body:
A `View` is totally optional, from what I can tell. It's under-documented in the README. Could you either explain what it's used for, and why someone would care, or split the README into the concepts that don't require a View and those that do?

I'm hoping to make Start even easier to learn and use.

Thanks!

title: Return Stream<Socket> from Server#ws().
body: Previously, this returned a Request which didn't match the actual type.

title: Refactor WebSocket Message parsing into an external pub
body:
Clients can't include the Start library as it uses parts of the Dart stdlib not accessable in the web browser. That said, it would be good if there was some common code which allowed WebSocket messages to be consistently serialized and de-serialized between the client and server.

I'm going to work on building this external pub, then including it in the list of Start's dependencies but obviously wanted to hear your thoughts before I started work.

title: Use HttpRequest.uri.queryParameters.
body:
HttpRequest.queryParameters is deprecated. (See
https://groups.google.com/a/dartlang.org/d/msg/misc/Y2UrfSEW6uA/-ZKCV-vLYUcJ)

This is a breaking change, so people not using the newest version of Dart would probably want to hold off on upgrading. Do you want me to iterate the Start version number to indicate this is a breaking change?

title: Add data argument to socket messages
body:
This resolves issue https://github.com/lvivski/start/issues/15, allowing data to optionally be passed to Socket messsage handlers. This also formalizes the concept of a Socket Message.

Also added tests. :)

title: Cookie expiration date weekdays are off by one
body: The `stringifyDate()` method of Cookie (https://github.com/lvivski/start/blob/master/lib/src/cookie.dart#L48) gets the weekday wrong by one, and throws an error if it's Sunday. `DateTime.weekday` returns a value between 1 and 7, but the method assumes it's between 0 and 6.

title: Support the passing of data via websockets
body:
Though being able to "route" Socket messages with the data seems useful, by using the entire contents of the data to do the routing it makes passing data associated with the message impossible.

Some refactorings to address this include:

a) Change the routing to work with JSON data, and look for a specific "msg" and "data" attributes of the parsed hash which would be used for routing and message data respectively.
b) Removing "routing" from the Socket and instead expose the raw data for the application to handle?

Thoughts? I can do a PR.

title: Refactored the way the files are included.
Start runs on the latest dart version now.
body:
- Accounted for the breaking `WebSocket.send()` -> `.add()` rename and
- Dropped the reflection since it has changed (`mirror.namedArguments` is a list of Symbols now, not Strings, which doesn't work with the `NoSuchMethodError` Exception.)
  
  I also dropped the reflection part because of the reasons stated here: #12

(Sorry for flooding you with issues,.. I'm just going through your code and wondering about a few things)

This means that I can't just use the types in my app. Why don't you include all the assets with `part "src/response.dart";`?

As such the example application is broken.

  start(view: new View(), public: 'example/public', port: 3000).then((app) {
                  ^
malformed type used.
#0      main (file:///i:/project/test/server.dart:5:19)
```

I have found the instruction about compilation of the views:

> Don't forget to compile views with bin/compiler.dart (views are precompiled in example).

But it is not clear how to do that. Can you describe the full process of compilation and installation? What should be done to fix this error.

The `pub install start` also does not work in windows, it shows the following message:

```
Could not find a file named "pubspec.yaml" in the directory ....
```

So I have created the following pubspec.yaml file to make it work:

```
name: my_app
dependencies:
    start: any 
```

and then I run the following command:

```
pub install
```

title: PyTorch support
body:
PyTorch and TorchScript support multiple serialization formats. Based on which format is used, a `.pth` file might contain only tensor data or a partial module hierarchy without graph connections.

[Saving and Loading Models](https://pytorch.org/tutorials/beginner/saving_loading_models.html) for more context.

PyTorch support is experimental. The recommended approach is to save the model to [ONNX](https://pytorch.org/docs/stable/onnx.html).

pytorch/pytorch#31877 for a discussion of the different container formats.

Sample model files:
[alexnet.pkl.pth.zip](https://github.com/lutzroeder/netron/files/5213453/alexnet.pkl.pth.zip)
[alexnet.zip.pth.zip](https://github.com/lutzroeder/netron/files/6096607/alexnet.zip.pth.zip)

title: LSTM internal weights in TFLite
body:
As you know, LSTM cell has four internal gates: forget, input, output and cell gate (https://colah.github.io/posts/2015-08-Understanding-LSTMs/) When we convert a model containing LSTM to TFLite format, we can see the internal weights in groups like "std.constant9" (with no specific name). But it isn't clear that which weight group is related to which gate. In other words, how do we recognize weights for each internal gate?
Sample files are attached if needed. Thanks in advance.

title: Highlight all nodes of a specific type
body:
Currently you can `ctrl + F` to search for specific nodes by name and have them highlighted in the graph. Is it possible to extend this to highlight all nodes of the same type? For instance, searching "reshape" would highlight reshape_1, Reshape_2, reshape/3, etc. This should support all the major types of nodes: concat, conv, unsqueeze, etc. Since the metadata for node type is already included in the graph, I imagine this would only require a UI update

Although you can tell some information about the node type based on its color scheme, I think highlights would be more helpful. Most colors have multiple types (green = gather, transpose, unsqueeze, etc) so you cannot zoom out and see the "big picture" location of where a specific type is used in the graph. As a machine learning engineer, sometimes I want to remove/replace certain nodes that run slower on specialized hardware, so this would be an easy way to visualize how frequently and where they are used

title: Appending of timestamp to model URL breaks mlflow artifact API
body:
- Netron app and version: 4.8.1
- mlflow version: 1.7.1

As described in #697 I want to automatically open netron with artifacts saved in mlflow. I got it working now, but stumbled over a probelm. In https://github.com/lutzroeder/netron/blob/main/source/index.js#L438 the current time is appended to the model URL as a query parameter. However, since it only contains a value and not a key, it somehow breaks the mlflow URL parser, resulting in an internal server error. My workaround is to simply remove this line in my deployment, but I would like to understand what it is for and whether it could be changed to a key value format. 

Unfortunately, it is a bit difficult to publicly reproduce the error, as one would need a public mlflow instance and enable CORS for netron there. I hope the problem is stll clear enough.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Track a keras model as .h5 file as an artifact in mlflow. 
2. Try to open the url in netron, an example URL would look like http://netron.app/?identifier=model.h5&url=http://mlflow.my-domain.com/get-artifact?path%3Dmodel.h5%26run_id%3D79a796f0dd5449b58e6e7e6d0a638f51
3. An internal server error is triggered in mlflow.

title: [Question] How to determine re-scaling factor for quantization?
body:
I'm working on implementing a tiny MNIST classifier on FPGA and was looking at this tool for inspecting the tflite graph. I know when performing an operation such as conv2d, the input and weights will be multiplied into int32 products. accumulated with int32 biases, and then a relu op will be applied. Then the output needs to be re-scaled to int8. My question is how do I determine the re-scaling from the info netron gives? According to netron, my input quantization is 
0 ≤ 0.003921568859368563 * (q - -128) ≤ 1
and my output is
0 ≤ 0.010280518792569637 * (q - -128) ≤ 2.6215322017669678

For the re-scaling is it simply dividing the output by 2.62? If I do that and plot a histogram, over a third of the values overflow 255. Is that kind of thing normal or am I mis-interpreting how to do the re-quantization? Sorry this isn't an issue, just trying to figure out how to understand the info from netron.

title: Change support for MSLite
body:
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->
<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
In the update of version r1.1 just released by MindSpore, due to the unification of operator prototypes of the cloud-end and mobile-end(mslite), the scehma of mslite has been greatly modified, making r1.1  and r1.0 not compatible. At present, the main users of mslite are our internal developers, and there are fewer external users. We have assessed that the impact of version incompatibility is relatively small. We hope to temporarily remove support for mslite and we will re-add support for the new version of mslite at about the end of the month. What do you think?

title: pth and onnx export different results on pytorch
body:
``` python
import torch
import torch.nn as nn
import torch.nn.functional as F
import torch.onnx
 
import netron
 
class model(nn.Module):
    def __init__(self):
        super(model, self).__init__()
        self.block1 = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Conv2d(64, 64, 3, padding=1, bias=False),
            nn.BatchNorm2d(64),
            nn.ReLU(inplace=True),
            nn.Conv2d(64, 32, 1, bias=False),
            nn.BatchNorm2d(32),
            nn.ReLU(inplace=True),
            nn.Conv2d(32, 64, 3, padding=1, bias=False),
            nn.BatchNorm2d(64)
        )
 
        self.conv1 = nn.Conv2d(3, 64, 3, padding=1, bias=False)
        self.output = nn.Sequential(
            nn.Conv2d(64, 1, 3, padding=1, bias=True),
            nn.Sigmoid()
        )
 
    def forward(self, x):
        x = self.conv1(x)
        identity = x
        x = F.relu(self.block1(x) + identity)
        x = self.output(x)
        return x
 
 
d = torch.rand(1, 3, 416, 416)
m = model()
o = m(d)
 
# onnx_path = "onnx_model_name.onnx"
# torch.onnx.export(m, d, onnx_path)
# netron.start(onnx_path)

modelPath = './model_para.pth'
torch.save(m, modelPath)
netron.start(modelPath)`
```

title: Acuity support
body:
Hi,

This patch enables the support of Acuity models, please help to review the patch, any suggestions are welcome.

Acuity is an AI framework that can convert the models of other framework(such as tensorflow, tflite, caffe, onnx, etc) to Acuity models, then generate high performance code for embedded platforms.

`.json` file is the Acuity model file which contains the model structure, and `.data` file will be loaded for weights and biases, `.quantize` file is for quanzation parameters. the output tensors' shape of each layer will be inferred if the input shape(s) are provied in model files.

Some popular models converted by Acuity can be found here: https://verisilicon.github.io/acuity-models/

Thanks.

#657

title: Fix Prototype Pollution
body:
Prototype Pollution refers to the ability to inject properties into existing JavaScript language construct prototypes, such as objects.
JavaScript allows all Object attributes to be altered, including their magical attributes such as _proto_, constructor and prototype.
An attacker manipulates these attributes to overwrite, or pollute, a JavaScript application object prototype of the base object by injecting other values.
Properties on the Object.prototype are then inherited by all the JavaScript objects through the prototype chain.

One of the `js` file to parse the `JSON` provided as datasets is vulnerable to a `prototype pollution` issue, which could lead to `DOS` or also `RCE` in special cases

Fixed by avoiding setting magical attributes.

### 🐛 Proof of Concept (PoC) *

1. Download the https://github.com/lutzroeder/netron repo
2. `cd <installation_dir>/source`
3. Create the POC file:

```js
// poc.js
var j_net = require('./json');
var res = new j_net.TextReader('{"__proto__":{"test":true}}').read();
console.log(res.__proto__.test);
```

Outputs true.

### 🔥 Proof of Fix (PoF) *

After fix execution will trow "Attempted prototype pollution: ... " and object will be not polluted

### 👍 User Acceptance Testing (UAT)

After fix functionality is unafected

title: fix bug: multi-input/output for Tengine
body:
Hi Lutz,

When rendering multi-input or multi-output Tengine models, Netron failed like this : 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21244722/93574788-6b2cd900-f9cb-11ea-90a6-6fbf5d77462d.png)

While the real model is like :
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21244722/93574972-a29b8580-f9cb-11ea-9b55-7e9afc90359a.png)

This is because in subgraph decoding, it gets `subgraph.inputs` are actually nodes but not tensors (also works for `subgraph.outputs`). 

I modified and successfully render like this :
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21244722/93575328-16d62900-f9cc-11ea-9e25-6e58873f7576.png)

ChangeLog:
1. Allow `Const` operators be pushed into subgraph ;
2. Read real `graph inputs` and `graph outputs` by `node id` ; 
3. Do not render `Const` operators

Here is the `tmfile` model attached so you can test.
[test_multi_input_output.zip](https://github.com/lutzroeder/netron/files/5244386/test_multi_input_output.zip)



----------------
Thanks,

Pierrick

title: Group and collapse nodes

title: TFLite: Support custom attributes
body:
Netron is awesome for viewing TFLite models, however the custom ops don't correctly render custom options, but show the raw uint8 flexbuffer array which is not easily human readable:
![Screenshot 2020-09-07 at 17 47 39](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/13285808/92403757-7150c900-f132-11ea-9270-482e135624f3.png)

It would be great if Netron would correctly render custom felxbuffer options. Recently there was an official [JS Flexbuffer implementation](https://github.com/google/flatbuffers/blob/master/js/flexbuffers.js) added that could be used to convert the raw data into human readable key value pairs.

I attached an [example network](https://github.com/lutzroeder/netron/files/5183913/quicknet.tflite.zip) with custom ops that could be used for testing.

`int64` is at least supported for ONNX models.

title: Make paddlepaddle subgraph selectable.
body:
The `paddle.Graph` class didn't provide  `name()` member function. All of the paddle subgraphs have an identical name "`undefined`".  So we cannot switch paddle subgraphs according to subgraph name.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1180139/91844772-99e84700-ec8a-11ea-9bad-10f4ef7d1555.png)

This change add `name()` function to `paddle.Graph`. Then the subgraphs can be selected and switched, as shown bellow:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1180139/91844896-d61ba780-ec8a-11ea-8ee5-9d414ce056f4.png)

title: CPU/Memory improvement: Replaced Array.concat where possible with Array.push(...) which is way faster
body:
Performance and memory improvement: where possible I replaced the Array.concat with Array.push.
According to [this](https://dev.to/uilicious/javascript-array-push-is-945x-faster-than-array-concat-1oki) Array.push is way faster.
```
The improvement has a lot to do with the fact that Array.concat creates a new array while Array.push modifies the first array. The additional work Array.concat does to add the elements from the first array to the returned array is the main reason for the slowdown.
```
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1175820/91159423-bd325580-e6d0-11ea-88ba-298b7a5594b4.png)

title: xxd hexdump encoded in source files support
body:
Feature Request: TensorflowLite .h files

Background:   TensorlfowLite .tflite files for mobile platforms can be converted into .h (C header) files for micro-controllers using the command

```
xxd -i model.tflite model.h
```

I assume there is a way to convert these files back from .h to .tflite , but I have not yet found that command. 
It would be useful to be able to view the Netron output directly from a TensorflowLite .h header file as these can be available from the web for micro-controllers without the corresponding .tflite file.


It would also be good to be able to compare the 2 types of TensorflowLite files with other models from TensorflowJS, Keras and Tensorflow.

title: [OpenVINO] Pre-requisites to work in parallel sub-windows
body:
@lutzroeder there is a demand from OpenVINO team to have two simultaneously rendered graphs. 

In particular, as far as we know, OpenVINO is an inference-oriented DL framework. During the inference phase original model (a.k.a OpenVINO IR) is substantially optimized and the optimized network structure can be also visualized (same OpenVINO IR-like format). Users can analyze and understand optimization by simultaneous inspection of both files. Netron is almost ready for that, we could just create a pair of canvas elements, sidebars etc. This will be made in the separate application that uses Netron, what I need from Netron as a library we base on is dynamic manipulation of elements from `view.js` and `view-sidebar.js` based on optional `viewId` parameter.

For recoverable estimator persistence scikit-learn recommends to use `joblib` (instead of `pickle`). Sidenote: It is possible to export trained models into ONNX or PMML but the estimators are not recoverable. For more info refer to [here](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/model_persistence.html).

title: How to render custom ONNX annotations
body:
Hi! First of all, thank you for making Netron and sharing it with the community. We use Netron in our quantized neural network compiler FINN (https://github.com/Xilinx/finn) to visualize ONNX, including as part of Jupyter notebook visualizations and it's been immensely useful. 

I would like to extend Netron to render some ONNX annotations but I don't know where to start, so I thought I'd ask for some help here first. In our project we work with few-bit integer tensors and we use custom tensor annotations in ONNX to represent them, by using the ONNX `quantization_annotation` field to carry strings that indicate the datatype. I want to add the possibility of visualizing the tensor quantization annotation next to (or instead of) the tensor shapes that are printed, something like this:

![Screenshot from 2020-07-07 14-49-08-edited](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1880902/86791507-842b1c80-c061-11ea-8ab9-8aa9bea329ad.png)

How would I go about doing something like this? Any tips would be highly appreciated!

title: Darknet: YOLOv4-tiny (detector)
body:
@lutzroeder Hi,

Feature-request: YOLOv4-**tiny** (detector) 

* **source code**: https://github.com/AlexeyAB/darknet
* **cfg**: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/AlexeyAB/darknet/master/cfg/yolov4-tiny.cfg
* **weights**: https://github.com/AlexeyAB/darknet/releases/download/darknet_yolo_v4_pre/yolov4-tiny.weights
* **discussion**: https://github.com/AlexeyAB/darknet/issues/6067

There is required only 1 feature:

1. Add `groups=` and `group_id=` to the `[route]` layer.
```ini
[route]
layers=-1
groups=2
group_id=1
```

So if input is `WxHxC`, it divides input into 2 groups `WxHx(C/2)` (there are 2 groups: 0 and 1), and loads the 2nd group_1 `WxHx(C/2)`.

If there are many layers specified in `layers=` parameter, then this will be done for each of the input layers specified in `layer=`, then results will be concatenated across channels.

![cmp](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4096485/85734112-6e366700-b705-11ea-95d1-fcba0de76d72.png)

title: Debugging Tensorflow Lite Model
body:
Hi there,

First off, just wanted to say thanks for creating such a great tool - Netron is very useful.  

I'm having an issue that likely stems from Tensorflow, rather than from Netron, but thought you might have some insights. In my flow, I use TF 1.15 to go from .ckpt --> frozen .pb --> .tflite.  Normally it works reasonably smoothly, but a recent run shows an issue with the .tflite file: it is created without errors, it runs, but it performs poorly.  Opening it with Netron shows that the activation functions (relu6 in this case) have been removed for every layer.  Opening the equivalent .pb file in Netron shows the relu6 functions are present.

Have you seen any cases in which Netron struggled with a TF Lite model (perhaps it can open, but isn't displaying correctly)?  Also, how did you figure out the format for .tflite files (perhaps knowing this would allow me to debug it more deeply)?

Thanks in advance.
